text: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2017 collection that was presented in New York on Wednesday.

headline: For Europe, There’s a New Threat in Town: The U.S.
text: LONDON — The European Union is accustomed to crises. But it is probably safe to say that none of the 28 leaders who are gathering in Malta on Friday expected the crisis that has overtaken the agenda: the United States of America.

headline: Oscars 2017: Where to Stream the Nominated Movies
text: Several Oscar-nominated films are still in theaters. Here’s where you can stream the rest.

headline: The Gumbo Bros
text: Cajun gumbo and authentic po’ boys from two sons of the Gulf Coast.

headline: Cajun, Far From Home, at the Gumbo Bros
text: Adam Lathan, the chef of the Gumbo Bros, lays no claim to the one true gumbo. “I can’t make it like your grandmother did,” he said apologetically. “I’ll try my best.”

headline: Santiago Calatrava to Design His First London Complex
text: LONDON — The Spanish-born architect Santiago Calatrava is known among New Yorkers as the designer of the World Trade Center Transportation Hub, which cost almost twice its original $2.2 billion estimate, an overshoot that has been attributed partly to him.

headline: A ‘Pounder’ of a Cocktail at the Reinvented Chumley’s
text: Chumley’s is one of those New York City landmarks with so much history it’s hard to know where to begin in telling it. The West Village bar was a Depression-era speakeasy; a rough-and-tumble watering hole for generations of writers, including Ernest Hemingway, Jack Kerouac and Norman Mailer; a divey hangout for N.Y.U. kids; and a bar tended and patronized by the firefighters of Ladder 5.

headline: Paris Turns to Flower-Growing Toilet to Fight Public Urination
text: In cities the world over, men (and, to a lesser extent, women) who urinate in the street — al fresco — are a scourge of urban life, costing millions of dollars for cleaning and the repair of damage to public infrastructure. And, oh, the stench.

headline: The Guggenheim Museum’s Deputy Director Steps Down
text: Ari Wiseman, the deputy director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and Foundation since 2010, is stepping down to start an independent design studio in Los Angeles with one of his brothers, the artist and designer David Wiseman.

headline: Deal Advisers Face a Tricky Period for M.&A.
text: Independent advisory shops face a tricky 2017. Evercore, Greenhill and Lazard, which reported estimates-beating earnings on Thursday, proved their resilience last year by weathering a choppy environment better than most big bank rivals. Continued success, though, requires confident clients. And they are looking for President Trump and Congress to ensure that happens.

headline: From a Sedan to a Drop Top
text: Customizing companies are filling the desires of people who want their cars to be convertibles.

headline: With a Saw and a Big Budget, Owners Transform Cars Into Convertibles
text: A few days ago, Jeff Moran fired up an electric Sawzall cutting tool and sheared off the roof of a new Dodge Challenger sedan. Next week he’s going to decapitate another car, probably a Cadillac ATS.

headline: Protests Force Speech Cancellation
text: Protests at the University of California, Berkeley, forced the cancellation of a speech by the right-wing writer Milo Yiannopoulos on Wednesday. He responded with his own video posted to YouTube later that night, saying that the left had become antithetical to free speech. President Trump also weighed in with a tweet.

headline: Yemenis Close Bodegas and Rally to Protest Trump’s Ban
text: Thousands of Yemeni-Americans and their supporters rallied in Brooklyn on Thursday to denounce President Trump’s executive order on immigration, hours after hundreds of Yemeni-owned bodegas and grocery stores around New York closed to protest the order.

headline: How Trump Would Corrupt the Pulpit
text: President Trump just reiterated his campaign promise to “get rid of and totally destroy” the law prohibiting churches and other nonprofit tax-exempt institutions from endorsing political candidates.

headline: Étienne Tshisekedi, Congo Opposition Leader for Decades, Dies at 84
text: Étienne Tshisekedi, a cunning and relentless Congolese opposition leader who was a thorn in the side of his country’s big men for decades, died on Wednesday in Brussels. He was 84.

headline: Refugees Annotate Trump’s Executive Order
text: Shock, confusion and despair in response to the president's decision.

headline: Angelina Jolie: Refugee Policy Should Be Based on Facts, Not Fear
text: Refugees are men, women and children caught in the fury of war, or the cross hairs of persecution. Far from being terrorists, they are often the victims of terrorism themselves.

headline: Republicans Move to Block Rule on Coal Mining Near Streams
text: Republicans on Thursday took one of their first steps to officially dismantle Obama-era environmental regulations by easing restrictions on coal mining, bolstering an industry that President Trump has made a symbol of America’s neglected heartland.

headline: Stampd: Men’s Collection
text: The label shows their fall 2017 designs.

headline: On Bernard Lumpkin’s Wall, a Visual Conversation About His Roots
text: When his father was ailing, Bernard Lumpkin felt a new urgency to understand the elder man’s experience as an African-American who grew up in the Watts neighborhood in South Los Angeles before moving to New York to become a physicist.

headline: Images of Nature — Taken Indoors
text: Federico Ciamei’s “Travel Without Moving” series features photos taken in the digital archives of historical explorers, and in a museum of natural history.

headline: Soccer Ball Heading May Cause Concussion Symptoms
text: Soccer players who frequently head the ball may be increasing their risk for concussion, a new study reports.

text: The designer counts Silicon Valley titans among his clients, and his own house is striking as well.

headline: A Tour of Ken Fulk’s Midcentury House in San Francisco
text: Age 51

headline: The Rehabilitation of ‘Pitbull,’ a Former Wrestler and Neo-Nazi
text: Duke Schneider is an aging professional wrestler known as Pitbull and a retired Rikers Island guard. And for eight years, he was a member of the National Socialist Movement. His devotion was first to Adolf Hitler and second to the cadre of neo-Nazis he commanded from his Brooklyn home.

headline: Riccardo Tisci Leaves Givenchy: What It Means
text: Yet another seismic shift is taking place in French fashion. Riccardo Tisci, the creative director of Givenchy and the designer responsible for redefining the brand Audrey Hepburn built for the Kardashian era, said on Thursday that he was leaving the brand after 12 years. A successor has not been announced.

headline: After Outcry, Murder Charge Filed in Death of Former N.F.L. Player Joe McKnight
text: A grand jury indicted Ronald Gasser Jr. on Thursday in the fatal  shooting of the former N.F.L. player Joe McKnight, handing down a second-degree murder charge. The charge is more severe than the one that Mr. Gasser had initially faced in December, when critics complained that racial bias may have affected the investigation.

headline: 10 Things to Know About Riccardo Tisci’s Reign at Givenchy
text: On Thursday it was announced that Riccardo Tisci would leave Givenchy after 12 years at the house. (The brand will not show its spring/summer 2017 collection in Paris on March 5 as planned.) Here, T rounds up 10 highlights from his time at the helm.

headline: Alfred Sisley: The Unheralded Impressionist
text: GREENWICH, Conn. — A reforming spirit swept through art history in the 1970s, when an academic discipline that once prized close looking above all else began to think about matters beyond form and symbolism. To truly see French painting of the late 19th century, historians averred, you had to understand their social history too — the urban reconstruction witnessed by the bourgeois Parisians in a painting by Gustave Caillebotte, or the health laws that regulated Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec’s prostitutes, or the class divisions expressed by the clothes of Georges Seurat’s Sunday parkgoers.

headline: Uber C.E.O. to Leave Trump Advisory Council After Criticism
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Travis Kalanick needed everyone to take a deep breath.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
text: Through Feb. 18. Bortolami, 520 West 20th Street, Manhattan; 212-727-2050, bortolamigallery.com.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Lion’
text: Garth Davis narrates a sequence from his film featuring Sunny Pawar.

headline: What’s New in NYC Theater
text: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages — and a last-chance pick of a show that is about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

headline: Garth Davis Reveals the Secret to Child Performances in ‘Lion’
text: What is the best way to direct the performance of a little boy lost? The filmmaker Garth Davis tried a few disorienting techniques with his actor Sunny Pawar in this scene from the movie “Lion,” which was nominated for six Academy Awards.

headline: Comedy in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.

headline: Riccardo Tisci’s Givenchy
text: Looks from the designer Riccardo Tisci of Givenchy.

headline: Snap’s Filing for I.P.O.
text: In its first public prospectus, Snapchat’s parent is trying to show how durable its business is. Snap is expected to seek a market valuation of more than $20 billion from investors.

headline: Film Series in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to film series and special screenings. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

headline: In A&E, Women’s Soccer League Gets an Investor and a Bigger Platform
text: The five-year-old National Women’s Soccer League has sold an equity stake to A&E Television Networks as part of a broad sponsorship and broadcast-rights agreement that will provide the league with an infusion of cash, steady national television exposure and something it may value even more: an investor committed to its future.

headline: Republicans Try a New Tack on Climate Change
text: Not long ago, many Republican officeholders had a simple answer when asked about the changing climate: What changing climate?

headline: New Faces (and Bodies) in Classic Roles at New York City Ballet
text: No performing art is more dependent on — more differentiated by — the individual contributions of its interpreters than ballet. If you don’t feel this art’s spell, try seeing any important classical work with two or more different casts in a top-level company. At New York City Ballet (more than with any other troupe), a constant element is the promotion of young talent to leading roles. Not so infrequently, you can see a junior dancer from the corps de ballet and a senior ballerina tackle the same star role on consecutive days.

headline: What About the Trump Presidency Surprises a Reporter Who Has Covered Him From the Start?
text: For those who spent months and months carefully watching the Trump candidacy, campaign, and postelection activities, what, if anything, is surprising about his first days as President? We asked the Times reporter Jonathan Martin, who began covering then candidate Trump in the spring of 2015.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
text: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

headline: Arguing for a Judge Today, and Before Him Tomorrow
text: Neal K. Katyal was for a time the top lawyer in the Obama administration. As acting solicitor general, he represented the government before the Supreme Court. He is no conservative, and says he is disappointed that the latest nominee to the court is from the White House of President Trump.

headline: Trial Documents Show Dylann Roof Had Mental Disorders
text: Acting as his own lawyer, Dylann S. Roof, the young white supremacist convicted of killing nine African-American worshipers at a church in Charleston, S.C., stood before a federal jury last month and insisted that “there’s nothing wrong with me psychologically.” But documents unsealed this week reveal that less than two months earlier a court-appointed psychiatrist had found him to have a host of disorders and that several months before the June 2015 massacre Mr. Roof had described himself as deeply depressed.

headline: Review of Trump’s Immigration Order by Office of Legal Counsel
text: The Office of Legal Counsel, part of the Justice Dept., released a memorandum on Thursday, after it was requested by The New York Times through the Freedom of Information Act, reviewing President Trump's executive order called, “Protecting the Nation From Foreign Terrorist Entry Into the United States.”

headline: Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.

headline: Women Rule Halftime. Can Lady Gaga Make It Rock Again?
text: Where did all the rocker guys go? In recent years, women have almost completely taken over the most highly visible gig in American pop: the Super Bowl halftime show, 12 minutes of music beamed worldwide. It is a ratings magnet, a marketing tool, a sponsor’s flagship, a cultural event and, of course, a live performance with no second chances, to be applauded or ruthlessly dissected, virtually in real time, via every internet resource.

headline: A Japanese Crime Thriller in Which Crime Is the Least of It
text: ISESAKI, Japan — Hideo Yokoyama is one of Japan’s most popular crime novelists. Yet he regards the crime as the least interesting part of the stories he tells.

headline: Netflix’s ‘The OA’ and the Transformative Power of Dance
text: A young woman, blind and adopted, disappears from a small town. When she returns seven years later, she can see. But that’s not the strangest part about “The OA,” a brooding Netflix series that involves abductions, brain experiments and a shooting. The real surprise is the choreography.

headline: Snapchat Parent Showcases Its Strength in Preparation for I.P.O.
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Snapchat may have been built on disappearing messages. But as the social media darling hovers on the cusp of becoming a public company, its parent is trying to show how durable its business is.

headline: Philippe Jordan, a Conductor Who Excels at Juggling Jobs
text: PARIS — It was 10:45 on a gray, chilly January morning here. The conductor Philippe Jordan was spending a rehearsal break on a couch in his spacious office at the Bastille Opera House, looking through the score of Mozart’s “Così Fan Tutte.” He had already spent an hour with the Paris Opera’s orchestra going over “Così,” which was two weeks away from opening in a new production directed by the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker.

headline: Review: ‘Youth in Oregon’ Takes a Family on a Contentious Ride
text: The only person involved in the making of “Youth in Oregon” — a gratingly awful family drama about assisted suicide — who seems to grasp the movie’s thematic potential is its cinematographer, Ross Riege. His warmly lighted, softly smudged images convey a world becoming slowly less distinct, as if being viewed through increasingly distanced eyes.

headline: Review: ‘Santa Clarita Diet,’ a Suburban Sitcom With Bite
text: “Santa Clarita Diet” on Netflix (10 episodes available on Friday) is an odd and yet oddly simple series. Think of it as “Ozzie and Harriet and Zombies.”

headline: Jaroslav Halak, Odd Man Out With Islanders, Settles Into Life in Minors
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — Wearing a home blue and orange jersey with his familiar No. 41, Jaroslav Halak made save after save in his most recent game, then was mobbed by happy teammates after his fifth straight victory.

headline: Review: ‘War on Everyone’ Is Missing Some Crucial Components
text: Squealing tires, firing guns, free-floating nihilism and an occasional look-at-me name check (Simone de Beauvoir) are all part of the package in “War on Everyone.” A compendium of strained talk and post-Tarantino clichés, this is a deeply disappointing new picture by the writer and director John Michael McDonagh, whose first two movies — “The Guard” and “Calvary” — popped with bright colors, splenetic jokes and actual ideas about people and the world. Mr. McDonagh’s palette and spleen remain mostly intact, but here he’s neglected to include a story or point.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Who Is Edward Snowden?

headline: Pointing to Trump, Groups Reject U.S. Aid to Fight Extremism
text: WASHINGTON — Community groups in Michigan and Minnesota have decided to reject hundreds of thousands of dollars in federal aid to fight violent extremism because of what they call the Trump administration’s vilification of Muslims.

headline: Review: ‘The Space Between Us,’ the Story of a Boy Who Fell to Earth
text: With the disappearance of video stores, there is something heartening about the existence of “The Space Between Us,” a cheesy hunk of science fiction from Peter Chelsom that once would have drawn curious young eyes to VHS shelves. Set in the near future, it plays like a transmission from 1986, when a boy and a spaceship’s robot pilot could raise hell in “Flight of the Navigator,” and Steven Spielberg set the blockbuster template to emulate.

headline: Classical Music in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Feb. 2, 2017
text: The New York Times film critics review “The Space Between Us,” “The Comedian” and “I Am Not Your Negro."

headline: Trump Looks to Another Finance Veteran for Senior Role
text: The founder of Cerberus Capital Management, an investment firm that owns companies like the gun maker Remington Outdoor and the supermarket chain Albertsons, is in discussions to join the Trump administration, the firm disclosed on Thursday.

headline: 7 New Books We Recommend This Week
text: Feel like getting away? Go ahead and dive into Arthur Conan Doyle’s London, explore the world of women in early Mormonism or journey across the Rocky Mountains to get a sense of how America’s geography has shaped its role in the world. Not far enough afield? A debut novel toggles between Russia and the U.S. across three generations, a South African novelist remembers her sister’s life (and death) in Johannesburg and a collection of poetic short stories is largely set in Louisiana.

headline: Review: In ‘A Good American,’ Examining Sept. 11 and Data Collection
text: “A Good American” opens with the voice of a woman calling from a hijacked plane on Sept. 11. The documentary then moves to an explosive assertion: It says that ThinThread, a data collection program, “absolutely would have prevented 9/11.” That’s according to William E. Binney, a former technical director at the National Security Agency and the principal subject of this film.

headline: Preterm Birth May Be Early Warning of Heart Disease in Women
text: A preterm birth appears to be an early warning signal of a woman’s risk for heart disease, a new study shows.

headline: Events for Children in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.

headline: Review: ‘Eloise’ Has the Usual Haunted-Hospital Clichés
text: Life is tough for skilled if unremarkable actresses like Eliza Dushku, who, despite early success, can be left foraging among fair-to-middling television series and forgettable movies. Even so, her career dips to a new low with “Eloise,” a horror movie of such ineptitude that it invites sympathy for even its least gifted participants.

headline: Review: In ‘Dark Night,’ Another Movie Theater, Another Shooting
text: “Dark Night,” written and directed by Tim Sutton, is a movie about a massacre at a movie theater. It was inspired by, and explicitly refers to, the fatal shootings committed by James Holmes at an Aurora, Colo., showing of the film “The Dark Knight Rises.” The wordplay of the title is sufficiently egregious that a potential viewer is apt to think, “Well, if it got a distributor, it has to be better than that.” It is not.

headline: Review: ‘Chapter & Verse’ Tells of Prison and Redemption
text: From the way the scene is framed, viewers can tell the beginning of this powerful movie is in fact its tragic-seeming end. On a rainy night in Harlem, a muscular man sits on a milk cart, smoking a cigarette, waiting. What he’s waiting for, a police car, is not long in coming. In voice-over, the man introduces himself as L, adding: “Check with your crew. Find out who I am.”

headline: Review: ‘This Is Everything: Gigi Gorgeous,’ a Self-Made Cover Girl
text: Gigi Lazzarato is very much a self-generated celebrity of the 21st-century vintage. That sounds like a possibly bad thing, and one of the achievements of “This Is Everything: Gigi Gorgeous” is its very entertaining demonstration that it’s not — at least not necessarily.

headline: Review: ‘Sophie and the Rising Sun’ Has Forbidden Love in a Foreboding Time
text: The veneer of decorum that cloaks the fictional fishing village of Salty Creek, S.C., does little to smother the stink of prejudice in “Sophie and the Rising Sun,” a genteel love story set in the autumn of 1941 during the run-up to the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

headline: Streaming Lava, Collapsing Cliffs and a Hawaii Volcano’s Spectacular Show
text: Off the coast of the island of Hawaii, hundreds of millions of gallons of lava are flowing into the ocean like blood from a ruptured artery. Starting in January at Kīlauea Volcano’s Kamokuna ocean entry, the lava hit the salty water, shooting molten rock upward and outward, accompanied by a rising, steamy cloud of acid.

headline: Harold Rosen, Who Ushered in the Era of Communication Satellites, Dies at 90
text: Whether you are reading these words online or in print, there is a strong chance that Harold A. Rosen played a part in getting them to you. Mr. Rosen, who died on Monday at 90 at his home in Pacific Palisades, Calif., was a driving force in the invention of modern communication satellite technology.

More people immigrated to America than in the previous 250 years combined.

headline: How to Walk on Hand Rails
text: “One of the main principles of parkour is a repurposing of your environment,” says Travis Graves, program director at American Parkour Academy, which promotes the discipline of running, jumping, climbing and moving in other ways through urban settings. “We see things for their potential, not for their intended purpose.” One way to start crossing those boundaries might be as simple as walking on a hand rail. Make sure it’s sturdy and stable. Wear shoes with thin soles or go barefoot. “That gives you a more tactile feel and allows your feet to interact with the rail,” Graves says. Being on a rail is similar to being on a balance beam, but because the former is thinner and usually round, your whole foot cannot be on top of the rail at once. “That makes balance one of the biggest challenges,” Graves says.

headline: Judge John Hodgman Rules on a Sad Desk Lunch
text: Rachel writes: For the last five years, my romantic partner, Stephanie, has been making the same terrible lunch to bring to work. She has a longstanding habit of unceremoniously dropping a few slices of Tofurky between 2 pieces of frozen bread, using no condiments. She eats this depression sandwich alone in her cubicle. In the past she has expressed envy over the sandwiches I prepare for myself. I would like you to compel Stephanie to devote the energy required to make a better sandwich.

headline: ‘There Was a Great Want of Civility’
text: This poem is from “The Traveler’s Vade Mecum,” a new anthology of poetry. The anthology takes its title from a 19th-century compendium of 8,466 numbered sentences designed to help travelers compose shorter telegrams; to use this system, the sender and the receiver of the telegram would each have a copy of the book and would communicate such useful messages as “I am onboard a steamer ship bound for Paris” by writing “45-Paris,” or ominous ones like “A sad accident has happened” merely with “461.” The anthology’s editor, the poet and novelist Helen Klein Ross, chose some of these sentences and assigned them to poets to use as titles. The result is a wide-ranging, pleasurable overview of many different approaches in American poetry today. Selected by Matthew Zapruder

headline: The Best and Latest in Crime Fiction
text: John Rebus is a downbeat version of his younger, scrappier self in RATHER BE THE DEVIL (Little, Brown, $27), the latest entry in Ian Rankin’s endlessly evolving series of Edinburgh police procedurals. Now retired from the force and hacking up his lungs with bronchitis or worse, the former homicide detective has gone a whole week without cigarettes. But every retired man needs a hobby, and for Rebus it’s brooding over unsolved cases like the 1978 murder of Maria Turquand, who was strangled at the venerable Caledonian Hotel while a party of rock musicians and their groupies was raging in the next room. And when the detective on that cold case is fished out of the harbor, the investigations intersect.

headline: Harry Belafonte Knows a Thing or Two About New York
text: Harry Belafonte’s New York was a lot like yours and mine. He was born in Harlem, got his first singing gig through Lester Young, his first acting role in a company with Sidney Poitier and his first lessons in a class with Marlon Brando, Rod Steiger, Bea Arthur, Elaine Stritch and Tony Curtis. He met the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in a Harlem church basement through Adam Clayton Powell Jr., and met W. E. B. Du Bois through Paul Robeson; his uncle Lenny, who ran a numbers racket, introduced him to the elite of Harlem’s gangsters. He took Nelson Mandela to Yankee Stadium, planned an Amos and Andy movie with Robert Altman and, at 89, he was a co-chairman of the Women’s March on Washington last month, along with Gloria Steinem, though his health kept him from the event.

headline: Uber and Starbucks Protests Show Boycotts Need More Than a Hashtag

headline: For the Disabled Traveler, Strategies for a Successful Trip
text: Terry Scott Cohen, 42, enjoys roller coasters, mushing in Alaska and tobogganing in the Pyrenees Mountains. Though he gets about in a motorized scooter, he has not let his myotonic dystrophy, a disease involving progressive muscle loss, curtail his travels. His father, Barry M. Cohen, 72, a retired industrial psychologist, acts as his travel companion, and together the two Floridians have written a book, “Travel Near & Travel Far: Step Out of Your Disabled World!” that provides both encouragement for disabled travelers and practical advice on navigating the world from a scooter or wheelchair. The elder Mr. Cohen recently discussed the book; here are excerpts from that conversation.

headline: Mirrors for My Daughter’s Bookshelf

There were talking cars, imaginary creatures and stories about white men, women and children. I started counting and discovered that only 4 percent of our books featured minorities as main characters, and only one was a black girl like my daughter.

headline: Behind the Best Sellers: ‘Girl Before’ Author JP Delaney on Pseudonyms and the Limits of Marie Kondo
text: The Life-Changing Terror of Tidying Up: “He may be an insufferable, affected, narcissistic creep, but he’s also a genius.” That’s how Chip Kidd summed up the architect villain of “Death by Design,” his 2012 Batman story with Dave Taylor, in what’s surely a nod to all the insufferable, affected, narcissistic architects in literary history — even the heroes: Howard Roark, anyone? Certainly the description fits Edward Monkford, the tightly wound minimalist at the center of “The Girl Before,” a psychological thriller by JP Delaney that debuts at No. 5 on the hardcover fiction list. Monkford rents his showpiece house only to alluring young women (who don’t always survive), and he rivals Marie Kondo in his aversion to clutter: The review in the daily New York Times was headlined, ominously, “He Doesn’t Like It When You Leave Your Shampoo Out.”

headline: Octavia Spencer Condemns Trump Followers Who Reject ‘Hidden Figures’
text: The past year has been a momentous one for the Oscar-winning actress Octavia Spencer, one of the stars of “Hidden Figures,” based on the true story of three black female mathematicians working at the nation’s space agency in the Jim Crow South.

headline: Cedric Bru of Taulia on Building Trust Through Vulnerability

headline: Kirsten Gillibrand and the Anti-Trump Left: 2020 Foresight?
text: When David A. Paterson, then governor of New York, appointed Kirsten E. Gillibrand to fill Hillary Clinton’s Senate seat in 2009, there was little feeling that she would become a key voice in a movement of resistance from the left. As a Blue Dog congressional Democrat representing an upstate district, Ms. Gillibrand had an A rating from the National Rifle Association. She had an uptown bearing but talked about the guns she kept tucked under her bed. Working as a young lawyer, she defended the tobacco industry.

headline: Oscar-Nominated Movies, Sometimes Streaming Near You
text: One common complaint about the Oscars addresses the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences’ perceived tendency to honor movies that ostensibly no one has seen. In some cases, the complainants are talking about prestige films that didn’t do a lot at the box office. A couple of months ago, I was listening to a podcast featuring two of the West Coast’s more colorful Oscar commentators, and one of them excitedly put “La La Land” in the category of films no one has seen. At the time, the movie, a critical favorite among festivalgoers, had not yet been released. Oscar commentators can be very silly people.

After years of study, the Environmental Protection Agency had announced in October 2015 that it could no longer vouch for the safety of chlorpyrifos on food.

headline: Trump Said the Unemployment Rate Wasn’t Real. Here Are Some Other Options.

headline: New Life for Dracula
text: In 1898, Bram Stoker’s “Dracula” was translated for the first time, into Hungarian. Just a couple of years later, it was published in Icelandic. But it turns out the Icelandic rendering was much more than a translation; it was a radically different version of the story. In a foreword to “Powers of Darkness,” an annotated English-language edition of that version, Dacre Stoker, the great-grandnephew of Bram, says the author “could not have been immune to the influences of the Icelandophiles who surrounded him,” people who had traveled to the country and studied its myths and literature.

In 2014, after a career of gender-fluid appearances on the catwalk for Marc Jacobs and Jean-Paul Gaultier, she underwent gender-reassignment surgery, which made her star burn only brighter: Ms. Pejic became the first transgender model to be profiled in Vogue and  to land a campaign with a major cosmetics company, Make Up for Ever. As she prepares for New York Fashion Week, Feb. 9 to 16, Ms. Pejic, 25, who lives in the East Village, spends her Sundays drinking tea, going to yoga class and eating a brunch with the works. headline: Bernie Sanders Talks Tuition, Free for All
text: Senator Bernie Sanders may not have succeeded in his effort to become president, but his campaign to place the cost of college higher up on the national agenda seems to be gaining momentum. In January, he was by Andrew Cuomo’s side when the governor proposed that New Yorkers with family income under $125,000 be able to attend state colleges tuition-free. Then Rhode Island announced its own proposal, covering two years but open to all in-state students no matter their income. At the federal level, with a Republican-controlled Congress, prospects for similar legislation are dim. During her confirmation hearing as education secretary, Betsy DeVos told Mr. Sanders: “There’s nothing in life that’s truly free. Somebody’s going to pay for it.” Still, the senator from Vermont continues to visit campuses and to push for federal legislation that would make tuition at public colleges free for all.

headline: The Trump Effect: What’s an Investor to Do?

headline: An Unusually Artful Task Lamp
text: Thomas Edison is celebrated for his invention of the practical light bulb, but in truth, this came roughly a year after a British chemist named Joseph Swan debuted a similar bulb in 1878. Edison’s innovation was longer lasting, evolving to illuminate the modern world, but Swan’s elegant lamp prototype, which burned for only about 40 hours, was a shapely marvel. Today, the designer Kelly Wearstler has created a minimalist task lamp in antique burnished brass that echoes his ephemeral creation. A can-shaped shade on an adjustable arm hovers above a base of cylindrical white Carrara marble.

headline: Review: In ‘Rings,’ Best Not Go to the Videotape
text: “Rings,” the latest sequel in the franchise that began with the Japanese film “Ringu,” is short on outright frights, but some effort certainly went into the storytelling. For one thing, by the time this one’s over, fans will know a lot more about the mysterious Samara, the dead girl who continues to terrify the living via a grainy videotape. And those nearing or in college — the demographic being aimed at here — will learn an important lesson: Beware of any professor who tries to recruit you for a research study.

headline: The Met Opera’s ‘Rusalka’ Is a Dark, Sexy Hit
text: The Metropolitan Opera’s new production of Dvorak’s “Rusalka” may be the unlikeliest hit of the season, a staging that takes opera’s answer to “The Little Mermaid” fairy tale and turns it into an almost shockingly dark, sexy drama. The mysterious look of the production, fantastical and ominous, combines with the sensual singing of a handsome cast to create a romantic energy rare at the Met — or at any opera house.

headline: Dore Ashton, Art Critic Who Embraced and Inhabited Modernism, Dies at 88
text: Dore Ashton, an art historian and critic who wrote some of the earliest and most insightful histories of Abstract Expressionism and the leading painters of the New York School, died on Monday in the Bronx. She was 88.

headline: Flying? ‘Bad Romance’? What to Expect From Lady Gaga’s Super Bowl Halftime Show
text: Speculation about what will happen when Lady Gaga takes the stage as the main performer at the Super Bowl halftime show on Sunday has been furious: Has the N.F.L. asked her to avoid talking politics? Will Beyoncé join her onstage? Will she cut a hole in Houston’s NRG Stadium and fly in through the roof?

headline: Rohingya Face ‘Campaign of Terror’ in Myanmar, U.N. Finds
text: GENEVA — Members of Myanmar’s Army and the police have slaughtered hundreds of men, women and children, gang-raped women and girls, and forced as many as 90,000 Rohingya Muslims from their homes, according to a United Nations report released on Friday.

headline: Violence at Berkeley and Freedom of Speech
text: To the Editor:

headline: Snap as a Camera Company? I.P.O Raises Comparisons to GoPro
text: The parent of the Snapchat smartphone app thinks it is “a camera company.” It’s almost as if its initial public offering filing on Thursday — which may raise up to $3 billion and leave the company valued at up to $25 billion — was somehow confused with GoPro’s from a few years ago, when the camera-hardware maker said it was in the media business.

headline: Nicki Minaj Scolds Shoe Designer for Ignoring Her
text: Another day, another social media feud. On Friday morning, Nicki Minaj took to both Twitter and Instagram to call out Giuseppe Zanotti, an Italian luxury shoe brand, for using her name in its designs and tapping into her fan base without offering her payment or a creative collaboration in exchange.

headline: On the Market in New York Region
text: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Scarsdale, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Huntington, N.Y.

headline: Residents Take Cover as Ukraine Border Battles Reignite Conflict
text: The embers of a smoldering conflict reignited this week as a series of border skirmishes in eastern Ukraine escalated to nearly continuous fighting along a front line, with deaths mounting on both sides.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re Reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: Justin Trudeau, Facing Pressure to Oppose Donald Trump, Opts to Get Along
text: OTTAWA — Just over a year after he became prime minister with promises of inclusion, optimism and internationalism, Justin Trudeau unexpectedly finds himself dealing with a mercurial American president who largely rejects those values.

headline: Dress Like a Woman? What Does That Mean?
text: What does it mean to “dress like a woman”?

text: See some of our favorite looks from the last leg of the men’s fashion season in New York City.

headline: Craftbar in Flatiron District Will Close This Spring
text: The chef and restaurateur Tom Colicchio said on Friday that he would close Craftbar, his 15-year-old casual restaurant in the Flatiron district, on April 30.

headline: Norwegian Ex-Premier Is Stopped at Dulles Airport Over Iran Visit
text: OSLO — During his two stints as prime minister of Norway, a steadfast ally of the United States and a member of NATO, Kjell Magne Bondevik met with Presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush.
