headline: Before New York Fashion Week, All Eyes Are on Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES — The night before the first big snowstorm of the year hit the first day of New York Fashion Week, Tommy Hilfiger held a runway extravaganza.

headline: Prince’s Post-1995 Albums and Music From His Vault Will Be Released by Universal
text: Ten months after Prince’s death, the last piece of the business puzzle for his music has finally been reached. Prince’s estate has made an agreement with the Universal Music Group for his music recorded after 1995, as well as material from Prince’s storied recording vault, Universal and the estate announced on Thursday.

headline: Afghanistan, Pope, Israel: Your Morning Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Mosque Fire in Texas Was Arson, Officials Say
text: A fire that gutted a Texas mosque last month was arson, but there is no evidence that it was a hate crime, investigators say.

headline: Viacom C.E.O. Sets a New Course, Focusing on Flagship Brands
text: The last year has been rocky for Viacom. There was the caustic fight for control of the company. The ousting of an embattled chief executive. And a push to reunite the company with CBS, then the abandonment of that plan. All the while, the company’s TV and film business struggled mightily.

headline: Video Review: Porsche Panamera Now Has Looks to Match Its Speed and Luxury
text: Although the car is dressed in luxury livery, even inexperienced drivers will sense the sports car in its bones.

headline: Driven | 2017 Porsche Panamera Turbo
text: The new generation of Porsche’s four-seater has lost the hunchback of the previous model and is now much sleeker. But the Turbo is still a rocket.

headline: Russian Airstrike Kills 3 Turkish Soldiers in Syria in ‘Friendly Fire’
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A Russian airstrike killed three Turkish soldiers in northern Syria on Thursday, an attack that both countries described as an accident. Still, it injected new tension into a volatile corner of the Syrian battlefield as new clashes erupted between Turkish-backed rebels and Russian-backed government forces.

headline: Tommy Hilfiger’s Venice Beach Spectacle
text: The designer presented his fall/winter 2017 collection, a collaboration with the model Gigi Hadid, in Los Angeles on Wednesday.

headline: The Gag Rule, Expanded
text: To the Editor:

headline: 1941 | On a Day of Infamy, The Times Is On the Air
text: Times Insider shares historical insights from The New York Times.

headline: A Plan to Prune the City’s Thicket of Warrants for Petty Offenses
text: There are 1.5 million low-level warrants on file in New York, demanding arrests for offenses so minor that many are not even categorized as crimes.

headline: Let’s All Read Together
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘A Patriotic Duty’: Dissent at the State Department
text: To the Editor:

headline: Elegant, Modern Furniture — for Kids
text: When the designer and Kinder Modern gallery founder Lora Appleton pages through design and décor magazines, she’s always struck by what’s missing. “You see all these gorgeous homes, and you’re like, ‘Oh my god, that’s amazing. Where are the kids?’” she says with a laugh. “We’re not putting them in boxes, they’re definitely all over the place, but for some reason, in a luxury lifestyle snap, we never really see that.”

headline: Trump, the Courts and Nordstrom
text: To the Editor:

headline: Kenyan Court Blocks Plan to Close Dadaab Refugee Camp
text: More than a quarter of a million Somali refugees got a huge break on Thursday.

headline: 5 New Designers to Watch This Season
text: In 2013, Sam Linder and Kirk Millar founded Linder, a men’s wear boutique in SoHo — and in February 2016, they presented their first men’s wear collection at a boxing ring in New York. (Since then, the collection has been picked up by stores like Opening Ceremony and Boon the Shop in South Korea.) This week, they will debut women’s wear during New York Fashion Week — alongside new men’s wear offerings. Both collections were designed simultaneously, and utilize shared fabrics. “We did some unorthodox things with men’s wear last season that were seen as gender-bending, but what we do is not genderless,” Linder says. “Adding styles that are specifically women’s wear gives us more to play with.” The pieces showing this week will include a cinched-waist column gown made of off-white denim and a checked patent leather blazer.

headline: Intimate Photos Inspired by a New England Family
text: Frances F. Denny’s personal, delicate series “Let Virtue Be Your Guide” emerged from her upbringing.

headline: Exiled Former President of Maldives Plans to Seek Office Again
text: NEW DELHI — A former president of the Maldives, who now lives in exile in London, is planning to run in his party’s internal primaries with the hope of becoming a presidential candidate in elections in the country next year.

headline: Next Fight for Anthem and Cigna: The Breakup Fee
text: Anthem and Cigna may have one fight left. Their $54 billion deal was nixed on Wednesday by a federal judge, who agreed with the Justice Department’s concerns about competition. In addition to fighting the government, the two health insurers had been squabbling with each other over the merger. That suggests that the payment of the breakup fee could be contentious, too.

headline: Red Carpet Watch: Amy Adams
text: Ms. Adams, a Bafta nominee for her role in “Arrival,” has seemed most comfortable in Tom Ford’s sleek designs this awards season.

headline: For Amy Adams, Her Director Is Her Designer
text: Compared with her fellow Bafta best actress nominees — women like Natalie Portman, Emma Stone and Meryl Streep, all of whom experienced early success — Amy Adams has tread a slower ascent. Yet there is no question that Ms. Adams has fully arrived. She stars in two of the most talked-about films of the awards season, “Nocturnal Animals,” directed by Tom Ford, and the sci-fi drama “Arrival,” for which she is nominated.

headline: Hateful Threats Against a Jewish Blogger
text: This Week in Hate highlights hate crimes and harassment around the country since the election of President Trump.

headline: Papa Wanted Temptations Played at His Funeral. Mom Says No.
text: My father died last week. I flew home to help my mom and sister make the funeral arrangements. Here’s the thing: A few times, over the years, my dad and I talked about playing the song “Papa Was a Rolling Stone” at his service. My mother said she never heard anything about it and is violently opposed to including a pop song in his religious ceremony. I don’t want to upset her more than she already is. My father died unexpectedly and pretty young. But I think it’s disrespectful of her not to honor his wishes. You?

headline: ‘American Idol’ May Get a Second Act
text: Even by the standards of an industry all too happy to revive canceled shows, this is exceptionally fast.

headline: Teaching Orwell and ’1984’ With The New York Times
text: In 1949, when George Orwell’s “1984” was first published, The New York Times book reviewer wrote that, though it was “not impressive as a novel about particular human beings,” as a “prophecy and a warning” it was “superb.”

headline: Paris to Increase Security Around Eiffel Tower
text: PARIS — The iron lady, as the French affectionately call the Eiffel Tower, is getting a security upgrade.

headline: The Lesson of Nordstrom: Do Business With the Trumps or Else
text: It is a clear violation of federal ethics rules for White House staff members, or any other federal employees, to use their official positions for private gain. But what President Trump did on Wednesday in his Twitter attack on the Nordstrom department store chain, castigating it for dropping Ms. Trump’s line, was far worse.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix Canada in February
text: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site.

headline: Review: ‘Speed Sisters,’ Revving to Go in the West Bank
text: Unconventional in form as well as content, “Speed Sisters” is a sports-underdog documentary that pays only lip service to the genre’s typical strive-setback-win narrative arc. Loose and unforced, this debut feature from Amber Fares explores the rewards and challenges of belonging to the first female streetcar racing team in the Middle East.

headline: Brock Collection: Fall 2017
text: The fall collection from the husband and wife duo, Kristopher Brock and Laura Vassar.

headline: ‘I Felt Like I Belonged There’: Transgender Cub Scout Breaks Barrier
text: Joe Maldonado, 9, was in the car with his mother when she got the call in November telling them that he was barred from the Boy Scouts.

headline: Ivanka Trump, Nordstrom and an Ill-Fitting Approach to the U.S. Economy
text: Ivanka Trump’s business just absorbed some blows. But more damaging than Nordstrom’s decision to drop her clothing line might have been the reaction from her father, the president. His lashing out at the upscale department store seems to reflect an approach to industrial policy that often brings unintended consequences.

headline: Love a Piece of Art? Grab It While You Can
text: MIAMI BEACH — If there is one thing Norman and Irma Braman have learned over their many years of collecting, it is this: Do not hesitate. Acting decisively has enabled them to secure the prized artworks that fill their home here overlooking Indian Creek. There are Picassos, Warhols, de Koonings and an entire room full of Calders.

headline: Review: In ‘1 Night,’ a Hotel, 2 Couples, a Bad Prom and a Reckoning
text: Minhal Baig’s first feature, “1 Night,” seems to be merely a sweet but slight romantic study for most of the way, yet a little flourish at the end makes it a much smarter film than it appeared. It also makes you curious to see what this young director will do next.

headline: Painting From the 1980s, When Brash Met Flash
text: In New York at the end of the 1970s, many people thought painting was all washed up. And if not washed up, it had to be abstract — the more austere, unemotional and geometric, the better.

headline: Review: ‘Left on Purpose’ Follows a Man Who Plans to Kill Himself
text: A bonfire of documentary ethics, “Left on Purpose” combines two nonfiction subgenres. The first is the embed-with-a-hoarder movie (“Grey Gardens,” the recent “Almost There”), in which the camera follows a disheveled subject who has partly withdrawn from society and lives in a clutter-filled home.

headline: Trump and Abe to Talk: Why They Are Meeting and What They’ll Discuss
text: HONG KONG — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, the first world leader to meet Donald J. Trump after the election in November, plans to meet with the president in Washington on Friday in the Oval Office. Mr. Abe is then planning to fly to Mr. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago resort in Palm Beach, Fla., to play golf with the president.

headline: In an Age of Alternative Facts, Bill Nye’s New Show Brings Real Ones
text: As he prepares to launch a fact-filled show into a fact-challenged world, Bill Nye, a.k.a. the Science Guy, is looking on the bright side.

headline: Review: ‘John Wick: Chapter 2,’ a Roman Holiday With Shots Not Sparks
text: They just couldn’t leave it alone. The original “John Wick,” about an über assassin who’s reluctantly drawn out of retirement, was a near perfect synergy of simple premise and intricate movement — an action movie that danced. But the lightness and winking quality that softened the slaughter are less evident in “John Wick: Chapter 2,” an altogether more solemn affair weighed down by the philosophy that more is always more.

headline: Review: ‘The Island Funeral’ Goes on a Restless Road Trip
text: The Thai director Pimpaka Towira’s second feature, “The Island Funeral,” is a road movie that’s as mesmerizing as it is tense. The film begins with three young adults — Laila (Heen Sasithorn); her brother, Zugood (Aukrit Pornsumpunsuk); and his unnamed pal (Yossawat Sittiwong) — standing by their idling car, wondering how to get to where they’re going. Laila is disdainful of her brother’s map-reading abilities, while the pal is frustrated that he can’t access GPS from his phone.

headline: The Artist Vija Celmins Conjures Sea and Sky With a Brush
text: There’s something fitting about interviewing the painter and sculptor Vija Celmins after sundown. And not only because she’s a night owl, known to labor over canvases long into the evening in her studio on Crosby Street in SoHo, with a cat named Raymond Carver twining around her ankles.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
text: Through Sunday. Participant Inc., 253 East Houston Street, Manhattan; 212-254-4334, participantinc.org.

headline: Review: ‘Fifty Shades Darker,’ and Only Half as Watchable
text: The big tee-hee about the “Fifty Shades of Grey” phenomenon is that it’s brought ostensibly scandalous heterosexual sex — with its whips and restraints — out of the shadows and into the mainstream. The likes of Madonna and the photographer Helmut Newton had primed that pump long ago, turning dominance, submission and toys into an acceptable spectacle. But it apparently took a writer as terrible as E L James, the author of the “Fifty Shades” series, to really hit the commercial sweet spot. The result is a clutch of best sellers, a hit movie (based on the first book, “Fifty Shades of Grey”) and now a sequel, “Fifty Shades Darker,” that’s almost bad enough to recommend.

headline: Review: ‘Eagles of Death Metal’ Revisits the Paris Terror Attack
text: Colin Hanks has a lot of experience as an actor but little as a documentary filmmaker. He set himself a formidable challenge with “Eagles of Death Metal: Nos Amis (Our Friends),” his documentary about the American rock band that was performing at the Bataclan concert hall in Paris on Nov. 13, 2015, when terrorists killed 90 people there.

headline: Review: Juggling ‘Stray Bullets’ and Homework
text: “Stray Bullets” feels as if it were made by a capable high schooler, and that’s not a slight. Indeed, the director, Jack Fessenden, had to juggle “trigonometry homework or my ‘Canterbury Tales’ reading” with his moviemaking responsibilities, he says in his production notes. He was all of 16 when he finished this crime tale.

headline: Germans Sent Gold Away to Keep It From the Soviets. Now Much of It Is Back.
text: FRANKFURT — Germans who never really warmed up to the euro may be able to sleep a little easier.

headline: Push for Contentious DNA Method Outlasts the Case Calling for It
text: When law enforcement officials began a push to use an ethically complicated forensic technique involving DNA in New York, they based their appeal on a high-profile case that had gone unsolved for months: the murder of Karina Vetrano, a 30-year-old jogger, in Queens last summer.

headline: Review: ‘Don’t Hang Up’ Has a Menace on the Line
text: Do teenagers really still make prank phone calls? And even if they do, here in the age of caller ID does anyone still answer a phone displaying an unknown number?

headline: Explanatory Memorandum by Muslim Brotherhood From 1991
text: A memorandum, written in 1991 by a member of the Egyptian Muslim Brotherhood, outlined a strategic plan in the United States that involved “eliminating and destroying the Western civilization from within.” Critics emphasize a page in the document where more than two dozen Muslim-American groups are listed under the heading “our organizations and the organizations of our friends.” But skeptics point out that, on the same page, the author wrote “imagine if they all march according to one plan,” which suggests that they were not.

headline: Raymond Pettibon, Wielding an Art Mightier Than the Sword
text: To hazards like icecap cracks, nuclear leaks and rising seas, add another environmental threat: language fallout. Never has verbiage, generated by advertising, the entertainment industry and mouthy politicians, been so present and pervasive in everyday life, seeping from smartphones, spewing from flat screens. And few artists have more cannily predicted and reflected, not to mention contributed to, this phenomenon than Raymond Pettibon, whose career retrospective, with more than 700 annotated drawings and paintings, fills three floors and the lobby of the New Museum.

headline: Review: ‘Land of Mine,’ an Oscar Nominee, Explores Postwar Perils and Ethics
text: In 1945, Germany ended its occupation of Denmark, leaving hundreds of thousands of land mines buried on the beaches of that country’s western coast. The dangerous job of clearing them was given to German prisoners of war, a punishment that seems at once intuitively fair and obviously cruel. That ethical tension — between justice and vengeance — is the subject of Martin Zandvliet’s “Land of Mine,” a tight and suspenseful film that is one of the five nominees for the foreign language film Oscar.

headline: Widening Crackdown, Egypt Shutters Group That Treats Torture Victims
text: CAIRO — The Egyptian police on Thursday shut down the offices of an organization that treats victims of torture and violence in the latest escalation of a harsh government crackdown against human rights defenders and civil liberties groups.

headline: Comedy in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.

headline: Review: ‘I Am Jane Doe’ Takes Aim at Escort Ads
text: Some documentaries inspire so much sympathy for their subjects — and outrage on their behalf — that it’s all too easy to miss the fact that what we’re watching is more advocacy than argument.

headline: Today in Mosul: Retaken Parts of ISIS Stronghold Return to Life
text: Ms. Callimachi, a Times correspondent who reports on jihadist groups, is in Iraq to cover the battle against the Islamic State.

headline: Film Series in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to film series and special screenings. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
text: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

headline: Review: ‘Sex Doll,’ a High-End Prostitute With a Persistent Follower
text: “Sex Doll” is a salacious title, but this superficially mysterious character study from Sylvie Verheyde is constructed more like a Russian doll: The script peels away layers of possibility until it becomes clear that there is almost nothing underneath. The movie doesn’t credit any source material, but it plays like a poorly dramatized magazine exposé.

headline: Blaxploitation Movies Are Ready to Stream, Nostalgia Included
text: The recent box-office success of “Hidden Figures,” an inspirational movie based on a true story about three African-American female mathematicians who played crucial roles at NASA in the 1960s, again has people talking about Hollywood’s relative neglect of black audiences. The newly started streaming service Brown Sugar, created by Bounce TV, which bills itself as “the first African-American broadcast network,” is an ostensibly nostalgic window into the so-called blaxploitation genre.

headline: What’s New in NYC Theater
text: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages — and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

headline: Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
text: This week brings some serious-minded nonfiction (Wall Street wrongdoing, covert wars, depression) and meaty fiction (an epic bildungsroman, border wars, a multigenerational immigrant saga) with a glamorous dose of diverting memoir from the actress and biographer Patricia Bosworth. Plus, a new book from Kevin Wilson, author of the beloved 2011 novel, “The Family Fang.” I’m especially heartened by the ambitious sweep of this week’s best fiction. There is nothing scaled-back or slight about the stories these writers set out to tell.

headline: Review: A New ‘Big River,’ Endearing but Ill Timed
text: Part dare, part warning, a written notice from Mark Twain hangs over the stage as the curtain rises on “Big River: The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn,” at New York City Center: “Persons attempting to find a motive in this narrative will be prosecuted; persons attempting to find a moral in it will be banished; persons attempting to find a plot will be shot.”

headline: Finally, a Screenplay by James Baldwin
text: “I have never seen myself as a spokesman,” James Baldwin once said in an interview. “I am a witness. In the church in which I was raised, you were supposed to bear witness to the truth. Now, later on, you wonder what in the world the truth is, but you do know what a lie is.”

headline: Off the Runway: New York Fashion Week Day 1
text: Moments from the shows of Brock Collection, Nicholas K, Desigual and Erin Fetherston on the first day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Modern Love College Essay Contest
text: We’re inviting college students nationwide to open their hearts and laptops and write an essay that tells the truth about what love is like for them today.

headline: Classical Music in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera.

headline: ‘The Ring’ Told Us in 2002 That the Medium Is the Monster
text: When the credits started rolling at the end of opening night of “The Ring” in 2002, several moviegoers were hugging their knees to their chests. The rest of the audience sat in stunned silence. As people filed out, a young woman, visibly shaken, asked her boyfriend to stand guard outside the bathroom door while she went in. Our collective shock was understandable: We were not used to seeing technology framed with such frightening agency onscreen before.

headline: Off the Runway: New York Fashion Week Day 1
text: A snowstorm didn’t hold up the runways on the first day of New York Fashion Week. Our photographers captured the action backstage and between the shows.

headline: Trump and ‘S.N.L.’: A Look Back at a Complicated Relationship
text: For the 42 seasons that “Saturday Night Live” has been on the air, critiquing the show has not only been the preoccupation of comedy nerds but also every American’s national duty. No viewer, however, has seen his criticism of the show scrutinized — or had the show get under his skin — quite like President Trump.

headline: 10 Standout Moments of Raf Simons’s Career
text: The excitement over Calvin Klein’s show during New York Fashion Week on Friday has been building for, well, months. That’s because Raf Simons — the newly installed chief creative officer of Calvin Klein — skipped last season to focus on rebuilding and rebranding the multibillion dollar American megalith for a brave new era. For Simons, the Calvin debut will be the latest of a series of memorable moments in his 22-year career. Here, 10 highlights from fashion’s favorite Belgian wunderkind and — potentially — clues as to what he’ll do at Calvin Klein.

headline: Review: ‘The Missing,’ With Children Gone and Parents in Extremis
text: There is no more dogged detective on television than the French child-abduction investigator Julien Baptiste. In “The Missing,” a drama that begins its second season on Sunday on Starz, he has the patience of Job and then some. Distressed parents don’t trust him; jealous cops won’t cooperate with him; and his wife won’t stop complaining about his long absences, but he just keeps working.

headline: Dance in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to dance performances.

headline: Jackson Hole Ski Resort Forced to Close After ‘Unusual’ Storm
text: Wyoming’s Jackson Hole got more of the snow that skiers crave on Tuesday night, but the heavy winds that came with it knocked out power and forced the area’s famed resort to close through the weekend.

headline: Art and Museums in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to new art shows — and some that will be closing soon.

headline: Events for Children in NYC This Week
text: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.

headline: Court Refuses to Reinstate Travel Ban, Dealing Trump Another Legal Loss
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals panel on Thursday unanimously rejected President Trump’s bid to reinstate his ban on travel into the United States from seven largely Muslim nations, a sweeping rebuke of the administration’s claim that the courts have no role as a check on the president.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Feb. 10, 2017
text: The New York Times film critics review “The Lego Batman Movie,” “Fifty Shades Darker” and “Land of Mine."

headline: Ninth Circuit’s Decision on Trump’s Travel Ban
text: Read the text of the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals refusal to reinstate President Trump's travel ban.

headline: Executive Orders, Kellyanne Conway: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Doctor Treats Children in Their Homes
text: Michelle Chien, 30, is a pediatrician with Heal in San Francisco.

headline: Scarlett Johannson, Donatella Versace and Naomi Campbell at Fashion Week Kick-Off
text: amfAR held its annual gala at the start of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Investing in the Pain of Student Debt Is a Tough but Tempting Play
text: As a college student in the early 1990s, Charles Trafton worked nights at a student-loan collection agency in Boston’s theater district, calling trucking and beauty school dropouts to ask them for money.

headline: Scarlett Johannson, Donatella Versace and Naomi Campbell at Fashion Week Kick-Off
text: In its unofficial kickoff to New York Fashion Week, amfAR held its annual gala on Feb. 8 at Cipriani Wall Street. A parade of models and celebrities walked the red carpet, including Iman, who filled in as a presenter for Lena Dunham, who fell ill. “I know it’s hard to tell us apart,” Iman joked.

headline: Hans Rosling, Swedish Doctor and Pop-Star Statistician, Dies at 68
text: Hans Rosling, a Swedish doctor who transformed himself into a pop-star statistician by converting dry numbers into dynamic graphics that challenged preconceptions about global health and gloomy prospects for population growth, died on Tuesday in Uppsala, Sweden. He was 68.

headline: Trump Signs Orders to Combat Crime, With Little New in Them
text: WASHINGTON — At an Oval Office ceremony for the swearing in of Jeff Sessions as attorney general, President Trump announced that he was also going to sign three executive orders “designed to restore safety in America,” to “break the back” of cartels and “stop as of today” violence against the police.

headline: Kushner Family Is in Talks to Buy Miami Marlins
text: The sale of a major league sports team always draws attention and local interest. But this one may attract even more interest, especially around the White House.

headline: Lindsey Vonn’s Pick for Downhill at Worlds? Lindsey Vonn
text: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland — Recovering from a broken arm and racing without any feeling in her right hand, Lindsey Vonn still says that she is the one to beat in the downhill at the Alpine World Ski Championships on Sunday.

headline: Lincoln in the Bardo
text: In this immersive narrative short, President Lincoln pays a nighttime visit to the haunted cemetery in which his beloved son has just been laid to rest. Based on "Lincoln in the Bardo," the new novel by George Saunders.

headline: Adam Selman: Fall 2017
text: Mr. Selman, known for his work with Rihanna, presents his fall designs.

headline: First Came Giuliani’s Input on the Immigration Order. Now There’s the Court Test.
text: Rudolph Giuliani, having correctly predicted the crippling October surprise of the presidential campaign, appears to have talked himself into the middle of a historic confrontation between the president and the judiciary.

headline: Stepping Away From an Idiot-Free Zone
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Do You Need to Worry About Trump’s Reforms? It Depends
text: I get it: You are freaked out. You don’t like this president. Practically every day, he sets off some new crisis and, according to your Facebook feed, does something that might destroy the nation. You’re wondering if you should start buying canned foods and ammunition.

headline: Lunar Eclipse and Green Comet Make for Busy Friday Night in the Sky
text: Two celestial events will take place on Friday night: a lunar eclipse and the passing of a comet.

headline: Consumer Watchdog Faces Attack by House Republicans
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the House Financial Services Committee will move forward on legislation to neuter the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and its power to crack down on predatory business practices, according to a leaked memo that emerged on Thursday and infuriated Democratic defenders of the bureau.

headline: Thakoon: Fall 2017
text: Thakoon Panichgul shows his fall collection.

headline: Neil Gorsuch’s Criticism Wasn’t Aimed at Trump, Aides Say in Reversal
text: WASHINGTON — White House officials insisted on Thursday that Judge Neil M. Gorsuch, President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee, was not referring to Mr. Trump’s recent denigration of judges when he said privately that he was disheartened by attacks on the courts.

headline: Barbara Harlow, Scholar on Perils of Resistance Writing, Dies at 68
text: Barbara Harlow, a scholar and author who brought issues of human rights and postcolonialism into the classroom through her studies of African, Arab and Latin American fiction and the writing of women in prison, died on Jan. 28 in Austin, Tex. She was 68.

headline: Kellyanne Conway’s White House Infomercial
text: In Thursday’s episode of “QVC: White House Edition,” Kellyanne Conway, a top adviser to President Trump, hawked his daughter’s fashion line on national television.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “She is attempting quite crudely to enrich Ivanka and therefore the president’s family.”

headline: For Charles Oakley and Knicks, a Long-Simmering Feud Boils Over
text: Charles Oakley has strong feelings about comped tickets. They are not freebies, he said in a recent interview. Instead, they are the vehicle through which teams show respect for former players.

headline: Nightclub on Wheels
text: RollerJam USA on Staten Island has a full-service bar and plays a mix of hip-hop, disco and the occasional Bon Jovi classic.

headline: Heavy Snow Blankets the Northeast
text: Up to 14 inches fell in the New York area, while parts of New England got up to a foot and a half.

headline: Luther Strange, Newest Senator, Is Ex-Lobbyist Who Thrived in ‘Swamp’
text: WASHINGTON — More than any other elected official, Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama laid the intellectual foundation for President Trump’s brand of nationalist politics, agitating for a hard line on immigration and trade while most other Republicans were in thrall to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and Mr. Trump was still firing contestants on “The Apprentice.”

headline: Lev Navrozov, Literary Translator and Soviet Dissident, Dies at 88
text: Lev Navrozov, a literary translator in the Soviet Union who smuggled out his study of Lenin and Stalin’s campaigns of terror when he emigrated to the United States in 1972, died on Jan. 22 in Brooklyn. He was 88.

headline: Phil Jackson’s Latest Twitter Message: Peace
text: One day after Charles Oakley was ejected from Madison Square Garden, Phil Jackson weighed in again on Twitter, although what he said seemed open to interpretation.

headline: Sexiest Job of the 21st Century
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — I always thought I had the sexiest job of the 21st century, but apparently I was wrong. Kyle Mahowald is back, and he says that the Harvard Business Review claims that the answer is DATA SCIENTIST. I guess Nate Silver wins yet again.

headline: Review: That ‘Sunset Boulevard’ Close-Up, Finely Focused
text: The scenery may have shrunk, but that face — oh, that face — looms larger than ever. So does the ego that animates it, both indomitable and irreparably broken.

headline: Review: In ‘The Mother of Invention,’ Middle-Aged and Not at Peace With Mom
text: As detectives know all too well, witnesses can recall the same event very differently. Adding thorny family dynamics to the mix complicates matters further.

headline: 6 Highlights From the Ruling on Trump’s Immigration Order
text: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit on Thursday unanimously upheld a Federal District Court judge’s decision to temporarily block the Trump administration from carrying out its executive order on immigration. The executive order would bar entry into the United States of citizens from seven majority-Muslim countries. Here are some highlights from the ruling:

headline: Flynn Is Said to Have Talked to Russians About Sanctions Before Trump Took Office
text: WASHINGTON — Weeks before President Trump’s inauguration, his national security adviser, Michael T. headline: When the Fire Comes

I don’t mean in your personal life, where you should keep calm and carry on. I mean politically. Think about it carefully: The fate of the republic may depend on your answer.

headline: What We’re Fighting For
text: When his convoy was ambushed during the 2003 invasion of Iraq, First Lt. Brian Chontosh ordered his Humvee driver to head straight into the oncoming machine gun fire. They punched through, landing in a trench full of heavily armed Iraqi soldiers. Lieutenant Chontosh and his Marines leapt out and he ran down the trench firing away, dropping one enemy soldier after another. First his rifle jammed, then he ran out of ammunition, so he switched to his pistol. He shot it dry, reloaded, and shot it dry again. So he picked up an AK-47 from a dead Iraqi, fired that dry, picked up another AK, fired that dry, picked up a rocket-propelled grenade, fired it, and led the group back to the Humvee, their attack having almost completely cleared the trench. Almost.

headline: A Chance for Trump to Save Our Streams
text: THE eastern brook trout, whose native haunts in the Appalachians are a short drive from my home in Washington, is a fragile species. It requires the coldest and cleanest water to survive, and over the past two centuries, its ranks have been decimated by all that modern society could throw at it. Today it lives in a fraction of its historic range.

headline: How to Tell a Ghost Story
text: “The most important thing is the setting,” says Ruth Robbins, professor of Victorian literature at Leeds Beckett University in England. “In the 19th century, ghost stories were read aloud so that the atmosphere set people up to be pleasurably scared in a communal way.” Britons in the Victorian era were obsessed with ghost stories because they reflected uncertain times — the Industrial Revolution, a move to urban living and technological advances like the telegraph, a supernatural-seeming invention. “Start with elements that you may be afraid of because of that atavistic, primitive danger,” Robbins says. “Bodies that are apparently human but might not be, like dolls and portraits. If the narrative begins in a room with those items, you’re more likely to be haunted by that space.” Material detail is powerful, because ghost stories are often about objects. “People become possessed by possessions,” Robbins says.

headline: Lost Body
text: The poems of “Constellarium” tell the story of the author’s transition from a biologically male to a female body. In long, gracious lines, the poems sweep through the events of this decision and its consequences. Medical procedures, emotions, memories and myth collect in the poems to reveal the many different ways it can feel to transition as a son, a husband and a parent. Selected by Matthew Zapruder

Friends made the trip and built successful practices when they returned. So we moved to Cleveland, where Ibrahim started his residency, and where we knew a few people from home.

headline: In the Dementia Unit, Cupid’s at the Table
text: When I was a girl, my friends and I believed in the concept, the imperative, of one true love. I suppose I’d arrived at my worldview honestly; even if the narratives of my upbringing — Maria and Captain von Trapp, Zeffirelli’s “Romeo and Juliet,” Jane Austen’s perfect couplings — hadn’t supported the true love/marriage plot, my parents were a living example of the inevitable right union. They were a higher order of June and Ward from “Leave It to Beaver”: the Cleavers with sex appeal, shared interests, enthusiasm for the other’s pursuits, and at the same time they were helpmates steering the ship. It sometimes seemed that our lovely old suburban house itself held their affection, the house the vessel for their love.

headline: The Women of ‘Star Wars.’ (It’s Not Who You Think.)
text: Jyn Erso is not a princess or a Jedi. She is, however, the second female character with a lead role in a “Star Wars” movie in the last two years. It’s a statistic that would have been unthinkable 40 years ago, when Princess Leia reigned alone in a galaxy of men and her dialogue was less than half that of the golden droid C-3PO in “A New Hope.” But even with the advent of back-to-back female protagonists, the women onscreen are only now catching up with those working behind the scenes at Industrial Light & Magic, the special-effects studio founded by George Lucas.

headline: Reaction in New York to Betsy DeVos? A Lot of Shrugs
text: On Tuesday, the day the Senate confirmed Betsy DeVos as education secretary with an unprecedented tiebreaking vote from the vice president, hundreds of high school students in New York City left their classrooms and convened downtown in Foley Square to protest the presidency of Donald J. Trump, both for his immigration policies and for whatever his Republican administration might do to the nation’s public school system. Antipathies toward Ms. DeVos ran high. “We love public school,” the students chanted. “Betsy DeVos is a fool.” It is hard to think of the last time an enormous group of teenagers would have been able to name the education secretary, let alone generate such impassioned feeling for whomever held the post.

headline: Going Home With Chloë Sevigny
text: As childhoods go, Chloë Sevigny’s in Darien, Conn., a wealthy town of 20,000 an hour’s train ride from New York City, was as suburban as they come: There was sledding and softball practice and long days spent playing outside with neighbor kids on the cul-de-sac where she lived, until the third grade, with her parents and older brother, Paul. “My mom would open the door in the morning, and we wouldn’t come back until the night. It was all about being outside,” Sevigny, who has been living in Brooklyn since 2013, says when we meet in Darien on a 27-degree day in December. The house, she remembers, had a big forsythia bush in the front yard. “It was, like, my spot,” she says, as we drive past gracious colonial-style homes with manicured lawns. “I always just chilled there, underneath. It was all very, you know ...” She begins to laugh, a boisterous, asthmatic-sounding, from-the-gut guffaw that signals she’s aware of the triteness, the irony or maybe just the sheer unlikeliness of what she’s about to say: “... idyllic.”

headline: Where a City Sees Decay, Neighbors Fight to Save a Community

Some of these tiny duplexes are battered by wear, holes in their sides. Dogs growl in cluttered yards. On a recent early afternoon, a woman stumbled down a street here muttering curses, as the words “Call your officer now!” emanated loudly, again and again, apparently from her ankle monitor.

headline: Headed for the Graveyard of Books
text: It’s a fine late-summer weekend just before Labor Day, and we’ve come to the Inn at Shelburne Farms, a charming old estate on Lake Champlain, far from the book-glutted world of Manhattan. But not that far: Thanks to my “stay connected whether you want to or not” iPhone, I get updates at all hours of the day and night from Bookish, Goodreads and Lit Hub bannering the new Hot Titles. I can be out on a lake paddling my canoe, and up will pop the shortlist for the Man Booker Prize. If you’re lounging in a rain-rotted Adirondack chair reading “Mrs. Dalloway” on your Kindle, put it aside. The new Jodi Picoult is here.

headline: Latin Jazz Is Booming. Look Beyond the Grammys to Find It.
text: When the Grammy Awards eliminated the category of best Latin jazz album six years ago, an outcry arose quickly. Musicians and advocates argued that the move cut off a rare source of institutional recognition for a genre at the commercial fringes. And the academy listened. The next year the category returned.

headline: Charles Schumer: Judge Gorsuch, We Won’t Be Fooled Again
text: Just three weeks in, the Trump administration has tested the limits of executive power, violated the separation of powers and shaken the very roots of the Constitution. A particular theme of President Trump’s first days in office has been contempt for the judicial branch as a check on his authority: He criticized individual judges, preemptively blamed them for all future terrorist attacks and ridiculed the court system as “disgraceful.”

headline: German Comedian Is Told Not to Repeat Lewd Lines About Erdogan
text: BERLIN — Jan Böhmermann, a German television comedian whose lewd poem satirizing Turkey’s president stirred tensions between the countries and a furor over freedom of expression, is back on the air and will not face criminal charges.

headline: Lemon Curry Fish
text: A buttery lemon-curry sauce is drizzled over fish for a quick and easy weeknight meal.

headline: This Sauce Makes Everything Taste Better
text: Here’s a plan of action that works for dinner any night of the week: Melt some butter; add in some minced garlic, herbs, spices and a squirt of lemon; then pour it over whatever you have your heart set on eating. With almost no effort, you’ll have a sauce that makes anything taste better.

headline: A Slap on the Wrist for Aiding Migrants
text: Cédric Herrou, a French farmer who has become a folk hero for illegally aiding dozens of migrants, was given a small fine by a judge on Friday. If he stays out of trouble for five years, he will not have to pay it.

headline: A Rare Survivor of a Philippine Drug Raid Takes the Police to Court
text: MANILA — The drug raid ended like so many others in the Philippines, with all the suspects shot by the police.

headline: Par for the Course: Tiger Woods Has Yet Another Setback
text: If only Tiger Woods had announced on Friday that he was withdrawing from next week’s Genesis Open in Los Angeles but still hoped to play the Honda Classic the week after that in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Then it would have been possible to suggest, gallows-humor style, that it was Woods’s allergy to Riviera Country Club, and not his back, that was acting up.

headline: Japan Limited Immigration; Now It’s Short of Workers
text: GIFU, Japan — Liu Hongmei was fed up with her job at a Shanghai clothing factory, where she worked long hours for little pay.

headline: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
text: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. This guide is a sampling of cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there’s much more where these came from.

headline: Lisa Gardner Catches Up With ‘Old Friends’ in Her New Novel
text: Crowdsourced: Some authors cultivate an especially collaborative relationship with fans. Janet Evanovich has let readers title her books; Neil Gaiman has solicited story ideas on Twitter. And the suspense novelist Lisa Gardner — whose new book, “Right Behind You,” jumps straight to the top in its first week on the hardcover fiction list — turned to Facebook back when she was still trying to decide which of her regular protagonists the novel should feature. “I wasn’t sure who I wanted to write about,” she told the New Hampshire public radio host Peter Biello this month. “Did people want the F.B.I. profilers? I’ve written some books with them. What about Boston detective D.D. Warren, who had a very successful book last year? What about Tessa Leoni? I really thought it would be between those two characters, so I was as surprised as anyone to have the readers choose the F.B.I. profilers.”

headline: Harlem Histories and Boardroom Lessons
text: Nearly a century ago, during the Harlem Renaissance, the activist and writer James Weldon Johnson described his neighborhood as “a city within a city, the greatest Negro city in the world.” But he wondered, “Are the Negroes going to be able to hold Harlem?”

headline: Trump’s Legal Options in Travel Ban Case
text: WASHINGTON — Shortly after Thursday’s appeals court decision blocking his travel ban, President Trump vowed to fight on. “SEE YOU IN COURT,” he wrote on Twitter.

headline: What I Love | Barbara Barrie
text: The actress found a “loft in the sky” 19 years ago and filled it with her best antiques. “The things I love are still here,” she said.

headline: Did You Take a Gap Year? Share Your Experience
text: The New York Times would like to hear from people who took a gap year between high school and college.

headline: Barbara Barrie’s Loft in the Sky
text: Nineteen years ago, when the actress Barbara Barrie moved from her enormous apartment on West End Avenue to a far more modest place near Central Park West, she endured some grief from her two adult children. They have yet to fully forgive her for selling the family home. But never mind, Mom got the sun in the morning and the moon at night.

headline: David Oyelowo on How to Play a Real King
text: In “A United Kingdom,” David Oyelowo plays Seretse Khama, the real-life king of Botswana (then a British protectorate known as Bechuanaland) who set off an international crisis in 1948, when he married Ruth Williams, a white British clerk. South Africa, which was instituting apartheid at the time, objected to an interracial couple’s leading a neighboring country; Britain opposed the marriage because resource-rich South Africa did; and Botswanans were angry that their leader had chosen a queen not of their race or tribe.

headline: Bella Hadid, Victor Cruz and Joan Smalls at Bergdorf and Rag & Bone Parties
text: Despite a punishing winter storm, the first night of New York Fashion Week forged ahead. Bella Hadid and other fashion insiders made their way to Bergdorf Goodman’s Men’s store for the opening of Nikelab. Ms. Hadid wore a fur coat over an all-white Nike ensemble.

headline: Chaos on a Hong Kong Subway
text: Passengers captured the scene on a crowded Hong Kong train when a fire broke out on on Friday. The police said a mentally disturbed man threw a gasoline bomb.

headline: African Nations Increasingly Silence Internet to Stem Protests
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Julius Ikena’s trade business is at a standstill because he cannot make electronic payments to his partners. Andrew Mofor cannot get access to the small fortune — 800 euros, or about $850 — that his daughter sent him through an online banking system.

headline: At Calvin Klein, Raf Simons Raises the Bar
text: New York Fashion Week blew into the city on Thursday amid a blizzard and a brouhaha (the Trump vs. Nordstrom uproar), but it wasn’t until Friday that it really began.

headline: ‘Planet Earth II’: A Lizard’s Great Escape
text: The most memorable screen performance of 2016 won’t be recognized at the Oscars in a couple weeks. For one thing, it appeared on television. For another, it was given by an iguana.

text: A museum in Queens has shut down an online art installation by the actor Shia LaBeouf, calling it a “serious and ongoing public safety hazard” after Mr. LaBeouf was arrested and the exhibit became a target for threats of violence.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Fed’s Proponent for Regulation to Depart, Leaving 3 Vacancies
text: WASHINGTON — Daniel K. Tarullo, the Federal Reserve official who led its efforts to strengthen financial regulation over the last eight years, announced on Friday that he planned to leave the central bank in early April.

headline: Trump Vows Quick Action to Stop Terrorism After Setback in Court
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump vowed on Friday to order new security measures by next week intended to stop terrorists from entering the United States, even as aides debated whether to ask the Supreme Court to reinstate his original travel ban that has now been blocked by lower courts.

headline: Summertime Rockettes Show Is Suspended, Needing Work
text: After two years of poor to middling reviews, a Rockettes show aimed at warm-weather crowds has been suspended and will undergo the latest in a series of creative overhauls, the Madison Square Garden Company announced on Friday.

headline: Surprise! You’re About to Conduct the New York Philharmonic
text: It was a tense scene at the New York Philharmonic on Thursday. Because of the snowstorm, the morning dress rehearsal for the final program of the orchestra’s Tchaikovsky festival was pushed to early afternoon. Halfway through, the conductor, Semyon Bychkov, felt ill with a stomach virus and had to leave. So Joshua Gersen, the Philharmonic’s 32-year-old assistant conductor, took the podium for the rest of the rehearsal.

headline: Inside the Mansur Gavriel Studio
text: The designers Floriana Gavriel and Rachel Mansur, along with the photographers Zhenya and Tanya Posternak, confer over all of the brand’s visuals.

headline: In the Studio With Mansur Gavriel, Where Instagram Is Real Life
text: In 2012, Rachel Mansur and Floriana Gavriel launched Mansur Gavriel — then a small collection of leather totes and drawstring bucket bags in a variety of colors. Almost immediately, the brand was a success: Within a month of its debut, there were already waiting lists at retailers for coming shipments and, by that fall, the bucket bag was one of the most prominent accessories on editors’ shoulders at New York Fashion Week.

headline: A Baby Formula Deal’s Success Depends on China
text: The success or failure of Reckitt Benckiser’s $17 billion deal will be decided in China. Britain’s cleaning-products-to-condoms group is giving $90 a share in cash for the American baby formula-maker Mead Johnson. Cost savings justify only around half of the $3.8 billion premium, though. Making up the balance depends largely on increasing sales in the People’s Republic.

headline: Long Before a Harlem Deer’s Reprieve, Clemency for a Cat
text: A cat named Tammany was living happily at New York City Hall in the 1930s. Then came talk of eviction proceedings.

headline: Katy Perry Dances Till the World Ends and M.I.A. Starts a New Wave
text: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter here.

headline: Where Camels Race and Win Beauty Contests
text: Camels, the ungainly ships of the desert, have been part of the history and folklore of Arabian culture for centuries. They’ve inspired poetry and song, served as transportation and racing companions, and have been a source of milk and meat for nomadic travelers.

text: SHANGHAI — Until he was appointed manager of a Taco Bell in China, Will Cao had never seen a taco before. When confronted with its hard, U-shaped shell in Los Angeles last June, he wondered: How do you eat it?

headline: Before ‘Fifty Shades Darker’: 10 Kinky Films
text: “Fifty Shades Darker,” the “Fifty Shades of Grey” sequel that chronicles the relationship between a budding journalist and a damaged business scion with an affection for whips and chains, is released in the United States today.

headline: Daytime TV’s New Star? Sean Spicer
text: He is no match for “The Young and the Restless.” But he is beating “The Bold and the Beautiful.”

headline: A New Designer (and Robert De Niro) for a Re-energized Zegna
text: Ermenegildo Zegna and Alessandro Sartori were reminiscing about a meeting the two had last year in the Italian Alps, near where both men grew up. Inside the brand’s Fifth Avenue store, they explained, they started discussing the future course of the family-owned fashion label Ermenegildo Zegna and ended up talking about almost everything.

headline: A Marriage of Art and Film at Berlin Festival
text: BERLIN — The power of a famous patron was on show this week in Berlin. The 67th Berlinale, the annual film festival, opened — and so did the first exhibit by a U.S. artist, Joe Ramirez, 58, whose work caught the eye of the German filmmaker Wim Wenders (“Salt of the Earth,”  “Every Thing Will be Fine”) after the two met three years ago.

headline: Microbes, a Love Story
text: This Valentine’s Day, as you bask in the beauty of your beloved, don’t just thank his or her genes and your good fortune; thank microbes.

headline: The Pace Quickens for Construction in Murray Hill
text: A quiet area is seeing new rentals and condos with plenty of amenities to keep residents happy and entice them to stay.

headline: New High-End Rentals and Condos Coming to Murray Hill
text: Murray Hill, long known as a go-to rental area for postgraduates, is going through some growing pains. With several new rental and condominium buildings popping up, along with continuing restoration work at the Queens-Midtown Tunnel, the once-peaceful eastern Midtown enclave is quiet no more.

headline: A Video, a Wheelchair, a Suitcase: Mystery of Vanished Tycoon Deepens
text: HONG KONG — In a newspaper ad, the Hong Kong billionaire declared that he was just fine, merely resting overseas. The local news media insists that he is helping with an important investigation in China. The police say he left the territory through a normal border control point.

headline: Shopping for Love Seats
text: Because a love seat is intended for only two people, it might seem like the ideal piece of furniture to curl up on for Valentine’s Day. But for city dwellers trying to make the most of small-scale rooms, love seats are appealing year-round, and may even take the place of larger sofas.

headline: How to Take a Cosmic View on a Trump Stock Market
text: The Trump stock market rally has displayed formidable staying power, yet there are reasons to be uneasy.

headline: Former A.I.G. Executives Reach Settlement in Accounting Fraud Case
text: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of American International Group, reached an unexpected settlement ending a tumultuous, decade-long battle over civil accounting fraud charges first brought in 2005 by New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer.

headline: Ladies Who Lunch
text: Benefits and galas were held last week for: Woman’s Day, the Society of Memorial Sloan Kettering, Waterkeeper Alliance and Lycée Français de New York.

headline: Ladies Who Lunch
text: Woman’s Day held its annual Red Dress Awards on Feb. 7 at Jazz at Lincoln Center. Net-a-Porter and the Society of Memorial Sloan Kettering hosted a lunch at the Rainbow Room on Feb. 7 to raise money for pediatric cancer. The Waterkeeper Alliance, which advocates clean water, held a benefit auction at Sotheby’s on Feb. 6. And Lycée Français de New York honored Christy Turlington at its Feb. 4 gala at the Park Avenue Armory.

headline: The Best Cities to Find Single Men or Women
text: Your chances for romance may be directly affected by where you live. That’s what a recent posting by Trulia.com suggests, anyway.

headline: Job for Chocolate and Candy Taster Takes More Than a Sweet Tooth
text: READING, England — Some people like to take a break from work with a quick bite of chocolate. But what if a quick bite of chocolate was your work?

headline: Illegal Voting Gets Texas Woman 8 Years in Prison, and Certain Deportation
text: Despite repeated statements by Republican political leaders that American elections are rife with illegal voting, credible reports of fraud have been hard to find and convictions rarer still.

headline: Will the Grammy Awards End With a Big Surprise?
text: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

headline: An Art Show Celebrates a Once-Maligned Material: Plastic
text: When DeWain Valentine was deciding what to title his newly organized “Plastic Show,” he paid homage to an exhibition he helped put together some 45 years back. “I named that ‘The Last Plastics Show,’” recalls the artist of the earlier CalArts exhibition. “There’d been so many shows regarding plastic and art that I thought it was the last one that I wanted to be in!”

headline: What We’re Reading
text: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: Betsy DeVos Is Briefly Blocked From Entering a School
text: WASHINGTON — The newly minted education secretary, Betsy DeVos, fled a small group of protesters outside a middle school here on Friday, at one point hiding in her sport utility vehicle as a man wielded a cardboard sign, before she finally entered.

headline: A Piano Rang Out Like Gunfire: The 8 Best Classical Music Moments This Week
text: Our critics are your guides to the chords that sent shivers down their spines, the voices they can’t forget, the set changes that left them breathless.

headline: Knicks Invent New Type of Loss as Owner Banishes Charles Oakley
text: The Knicks, who were already raising dysfunction to an art form with bad basketball and head-scratching Twitter posts from their famous team president, moved further into the surreal on Friday when the team’s owner announced that he was indefinitely barring one of the most popular players in franchise history from Madison Square Garden.

headline: As Fighting Escalates in Ukraine, Attention Focuses on Donald Trump
text: AVDIIVKA, Ukraine — Here at the epicenter of the latest spasm of violence in eastern Ukraine, great thuds of artillery shells could be heard in the distance on Friday, as residents scrambled to board up blown-out windows and stockpile groceries in anticipation of further shelling.

headline: Facebook Takes Steps to Improve Advertising Data After Criticism
text: Facebook said on Friday that it would agree to an audit of information it provides to marketers and provide them with new, more precise measurement data, less than two weeks after Procter & Gamble, America’s biggest advertiser, criticized the lack of transparency provided by digital ad platforms.

headline: Review: ‘The Dark Side of the Sun,’ and, by the Way, We’re Doomed
text: Americans’ fears of nuclear annihilation well up every few decades. Early 1960s: the Cuban missile crisis. 1980s: the Soviet Union’s reaction to the “Star Wars” defense plan. Now: “We’re going to war in the South China Sea in five to 10 years, there’s no doubt about that” — Stephen K. Bannon.

headline: Stairways to Adventure
text: Fire escapes give city dwellers a place to get away for awhile.

headline: Voyeur: Fire Escapes
text: We belong, we belong awake.

headline: What Happened to Elizabeth Warren Has Roots in Racism
text: This week, the Senate voted 49 to 43 to silence one of its own members. Whether the Republicans who forced Senator Elizabeth Warren, the Massachusetts Democrat, to sit down knew it or not, they added another chapter to a long and infamous tradition of manipulating congressional rules to prevent an open discussion of race.

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 2 Premiere: Neanderthals
text: Sliding along an earth-trembling bass line, Harry Nilsson’s “Jump into the Fire” is the first music cue on this season of “Billions,” and for a show that’s always curated its soundtrack thoughtfully, the choice is significant. Cinephiles will instantly recognize it from the final third of “Goodfellas,” when the story of Henry Hill suddenly shifts from a decades-spanning gangster epic to a frantic, paranoid, cocaine-fueled day in the life. “You can climb a mountain, you can swim in the sea,” Nilsson sings, “You can jump into the fire, but you’ll never be free.” Those doom-laden lyrics suggest that even powerful men cannot transcend their situation, and Season 2 seems intent on putting the squeeze on Chuck Rhoades and Bobby Axelrod.

headline: This City Ballet Dancer Has a New Role: Being Bad
text: Fairies can be so fickle. One night, all you want to do is break a spell. The next, with ice in your veins and a malicious flourish, you put a curse into action.

headline: Breaking Up the Family as a Way to Break Up the Mob
text: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy — Fighting the mafia at the very toe of Italy, Roberto Di Bella has seen a lot: children as young as 11 or 12 serving as lookouts during murders, attending drug deals and mob strategy sessions, or learning how to handle a Kalashnikov assault rifle.

headline: How Should a Musician Make a Debut? Try Going Low-Key
text: A lot was at stake for the pianist Dmitry Masleev when he made his New York recital debut on Jan. 30 at Carnegie Hall. After he took the gold medal in the 2015 International Tchaikovsky Competition, New Yorkers would have a chance to hear what the fuss was about.

headline: Street Style: New York Fashion Week
text: The start of the fall 2017 ready-to-wear season brings the well-dressed to New York City’s sidewalks.

headline: Street Style: New York Fashion Week
text: New York Fashion Week is in full swing, and with it comes street style. We’ll be updating all week with looks from between the shows. Come back soon.

headline: Ford to Invest $1 Billion in Artificial Intelligence Start-Up
text: SAN FRANCISCO — One of the oldest automakers in the United States is making a billion-dollar bet that one day, owning a car may not be a necessity of American life.

headline: Shinzo Abe, Executive Orders: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Pastry for Those Who Prefer Savory to Sweet
text: When I want a satisfying snack, more often than not I opt for something salty, spicy or crisp — a slice of pizza, a taco, an empanada. If I pop into a bakery, it’s the savory, cheesy items that appeal, not the sweets.

headline: Long Before Making Enigmatic Earthworks, People Reshaped Brazil’s Rain Forest
text: Deep in the Amazon, the rain forest once covered ancient secrets. Spread across hundreds of thousands of acres are massive, geometric earthworks. The carvings stretch out in circles and squares that can be as big as a city block, with trenches up to 12 yards wide and 13 feet deep. They appear to have been built up to 2,000 years ago.

headline: Hundreds of Beached Whales Die in New Zealand
text: More than 250 pilot whales died on the coastline, one of the worst whale strandings in the country's history.

headline: Review: ‘Unknown Pleasures’ Makes Unfulfilled Promises
text: Do you look at a dance work differently if you don’t know who made it? A choreographer’s name, like that of any artist, is a brand — a repository for reputation, necessary for fandom and crucial for marketing. But that same reputation can become a trap, compelling an artist to deliver the familiar and a viewer to expect it, with preconceptions and prejudices that can obscure the work.

headline: Rag & Bone Says No to the Runway Show
text: Marcus Wainwright, the chief executive and creative director of Rag & Bone, sat in his 13th Street Rag & Bone studio, converted for two days into two makeshift photo studios to shoot 74 portraits, with all of the chaos and confusion that entailed. At one side, the photographer Glen Luchford worked a Polaroid camera the size of a small car that churns out 20-inch-by-24-inch instant photos on ancient, rapidly expiring, no-longer-in-production film. At another, Frank Lebon coaxed his subjects into bouncing on trampolines as he shot them on film and an iPhone.

headline: Anthony Huxley, the Anti-Jock of City Ballet
text: In dance, “voice” can refer to the way a body moves, not just the words that come from it. It has taken Anthony Huxley, shy by nature, time to find both. For years, he rarely spoke. He could hide behind his impeccable technique. It’s almost as if a classical step, beautifully executed, became a kind of armor used to shield himself from the world.

headline: Svend Asmussen, an Early Master of Jazz Violin, Dies at 100
text: Svend Asmussen, a Danish jazz violinist whose collaborators over more than 70 years included Duke Ellington, Benny Goodman, the Indian violinist L. Subramaniam and the bluegrass mandolinist David Grisman, died on Feb. 7. He was 100.

headline: De Blasio and Stringer Trade Barbs Over Police Body Camera Deal
text: On a day when he might have been enjoying praise for a smooth response to the year’s first big snowstorm and in an upbeat mood over his coming State of the City speech, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Friday instead stepped in a puddle of slush of his own making.

headline: Mexican Government Rejects Findings of Misconduct in Missing Students Case
text: MEXICO CITY — The final version of an internal review by the Mexican government into the conduct of investigators searching for 43 missing students has rejected an earlier report that found that the officials’ mishandling of suspects and evidence broke the law.

headline: Review: It’s Norman Mailer vs. Feminists in ‘The Town Hall Affair’
text: “I’m beside myself. I’m beside myself,” mutters an anxious and excited Jill Johnston at the beginning of “The Town Hall Affair,” the very timely and time-bending new mixed-media piece that’s churning up decades of sexual discontent at the Performing Garage in SoHo. Johnston (reincarnated by Kate Valk), the poetic polemicist whose works included “Lesbian Nation: The Feminist Solution,” sure isn’t alone in feeling that way.

headline: 8 Things You Missed From the First 2 Days of Fashion Week
text: On Thursday, up to 14 inches of snow fell in the New York area. Flights and trains were disrupted. Schools closed.

headline: Ljubisa Beara, Who Oversaw Massacre at Srebrenica, Dies at 77
text: Col. Ljubisa Beara, the Bosnian Serb Army security chief sentenced to life imprisonment for genocide in 2010 in the massacre of as many as 8,000 Muslim men and boys near Srebrenica in 1995 — the worst mass murder in Europe since World War II — died on Wednesday in Berlin. He was 77.

headline: Jason Wu: Fall 2017
text: Mr. Wu, a favorite of Michelle Obama, shows his fall looks.

headline: At 35, Canadian Ski Racer Is Finding His Groove
text: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland — Erik Guay believes that downhill ski racers can improve with age.

headline: The Ties That Blind
text: Lost in the excitement and outrage of Donald Trump’s first three weeks as president of the United States was a minor sartorial scandal: The putative leader of the free world cannot tie a necktie properly. Compared with religious persecution at our borders and the unraveling of decades-old international alliances, this may seem trivial. But could a misbegotten (and far too shiny) necktie reflect weightier issues of self-discipline, competence and integrity?

headline: A Pianist’s Warsaw: ‘Fascination and Pain’
text: In 2006, the pianist Piotr Anderszewski took his first sabbatical. He had no clear purpose in scheduling a break from concertizing and recording — no special project in mind, like learning new repertory. He just wanted time to think and relax, to “cook a beautiful meal and share it with good friends,” as he explained in an interview last month in New York.

headline: As Ties With U.S. Cool, Europeans Look to Forge Other Alliances
text: WASHINGTON — The weather, and her reception here, were far colder than when she visited last summer during the Obama administration, but Federica Mogherini, the European Union’s foreign minister, made it clear that she can handle a chill in the air.

headline: Mike Ilitch, Little Caesars Founder and Detroit Sports Owner, Dies at 87
text: Mike Ilitch, a self-made son of immigrants who founded Little Caesars Pizza in a Detroit suburb and also owned baseball’s Tigers and hockey’s Red Wings, building a business, sports and entertainment empire that made him among America’s wealthiest men and helped change the face of his native city, died on Friday in Detroit. He was 87.

headline: 2 New York City Men Plead Guilty to Trying to Help the Islamic State
text: Two New York City men have pleaded guilty to federal charges that they plotted a pressure-cooker bomb attack in the city on behalf of the Islamic State, prosecutors said on Friday.

headline: Chicago Officer Who Shot Teenager and Bystander Will Not Be Charged
text: CHICAGO — A police officer here who fatally shot an innocent bystander and a 19-year-old wielding a baseball bat will not face state charges, prosecutors announced on Friday.

headline: Nicolai Gedda, Celebrated Opera Tenor, Dies at 91
text: Nicolai Gedda, the Swedish singer who rose from an impoverished childhood and a youthful career as a bank clerk to become one of the most celebrated tenors of the 20th century, died on Jan. 8 in Tolochenaz, Switzerland. He was 91.

headline: Tom Price Is Sworn In as Health Secretary Amid Senate Disunity
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s secretary of health and human services, Tom Price, took office on Friday with a promise to fix what he called a “broken health care system” that was “harming Americans and their families.”

headline: If Obamacare Is Out, Where’s Trumpcare?
text: With President Trump in office, the goal of repealing the Affordable Care Act is finally within reach for Republicans. Margot Sanger-Katz explains why repealing and replacing Obamacare may not be easy.

headline: Addiction Treatment Grew Under Health Law. Now What?
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Chad Diaz began using heroin when he was 12. Now 36 and newly covered by Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act, he is on Suboxone, a substitute opioid that eases withdrawal symptoms and cravings, and he is slowly pulling himself together.

headline: Syria’s Assad Sends Signals to Trump in Interview
text: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria suggested in an interview published Friday that he could foresee cooperation with the Trump administration and might even countenance the deployment of American soldiers in the country one day.

headline: Campus Politics in the Age of Trump
text: LAS VEGAS — Recently, I met with a former student of mine who showed exceptional promise during his freshman year. Since he took my class, he has become a leader in social justice groups and works part time at the university’s women’s center. He is now a junior and is on schedule to graduate a semester early. He is a model student. He is also undocumented.

headline: Soccer and Baseball Just Can’t Leave Well Enough Alone

text: A couple of weeks ago, people boycotted Nordstrom for one reason: The department store sold Ivanka Trump products.

headline: Buchi Emecheta, Nigerian Novelist, Dies at 72
text: Buchi Emecheta, a British-based Nigerian writer who, in “Second-Class Citizen,” “The Joys of Motherhood” and other novels, gave voice to African women struggling to reconcile traditional roles with the demands of modernity, died on Jan. 25 at her home in London. She was 72.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “We have a very, very good bond — very, very good chemistry. I’ll let you know if it changes, but I don’t think it will.”

headline: Trump Will ‘Look Into’ Reports That Flynn Discussed Sanctions With Russia

headline: Conflicting Views on a Wider Police Use of DNA
text: The question of how widely investigators should be able to examine DNA databases is in the news, as officials in New York deliberate whether to authorize a method that could help find relatives of people charged with crimes.

headline: Graduation Rate in New York State Hits a New High: 79.4%
text: The New York State Education Department said on Friday that the high school graduation rate hit a new high of 79.4 percent in 2016, an increase of 1.3 points from 2015 and more than 12 points from a decade ago. But changes to graduation requirements in 2016 made it hard to know whether schools were doing better or students were simply clearing a lower bar.

headline: Leonard Perroots, General Who Defused Nuclear Crisis With Soviets, Dies at 83
text: In early November 1983, after President Ronald Reagan denounced the Soviet Union as the “evil empire” and unveiled his so-called Star Wars missile defense strategy, Kremlin leaders were growing convinced that war games planned by the United States and NATO in Western Europe were, in fact, a disguised prelude to a nuclear first strike on Russia.

headline: Trump Foreign Policy Quickly Loses Its Sharp Edge
text: WASHINGTON — When President Trump took a phone call from the leader of Taiwan in December and asserted that the United States might no longer be bound by the “One China” policy, his defenders hailed it as a show of strength — the latest delicate issue on which Mr. Trump was willing to challenge decades of diplomatic orthodoxy.

headline: U.S. Blocks Palestinian Ex-Premier From Senior U.N. Post
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United States on Friday blocked the appointment of a former Palestinian official for a senior United Nations post in a move intended to signal its support for Israel and its defense of the position that there is no Palestinian state.

headline: An Anti-Consumer Agenda at the F.C.C.
text: As President Trump rushes to dismantle Obama-era rules that protect Americans, he has an energetic helper over at the Federal Communications Commission. Its new Republican chairman has started undoing policies of his predecessor that were intended to make phone, cable and internet service more fair and more affordable.

text: All these Trumps are getting damned expensive.

headline: America’s So-Called National Security Adviser
text: From the start, Michael Flynn, a retired army lieutenant general, was a disturbing choice as President Trump’s national security adviser. He is a hothead with extremist views in a critical job that is supposed to build consensus through thoughtful, prudent decision-making. The choice is now growing more unnerving every day.

headline: Reports of Raids Have Immigrants Bracing for Enforcement Surge
text: In Austin, Tex., undocumented women working in a laundromat cowered in the back of the room, petrified after seeing a video and a photograph of apprehensions outside a local grocery store and burger joint.

headline: The End of Caesar
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — You may have guessed that I get very excited when new entries appear in The New York Times Crossword, and you would be correct. There are a lot of things I like about solving puzzles, but seeing a fresh entry or even a brand-new clue for a ubiquitous term is like a hit of oxygen for me. If you’ve ever wondered how I know when that is happening, it’s not a matter of psychic ability (Those of you over the age of 40, please read that as “ ... it’s not some Carnac the Magnificent-like trick”), but rather the hard work of Jeff Chen and Jim Horne at XWord Info, who analyze and archive each puzzle.

headline: Canada Today: An Isolated Lake and a Welcome Mat for Refugees
text: Many Canadians may dimly recall from their geography lessons that Great Bear Lake is large and somewhere up in the Northwest Territories. Fewer, however, know much more than that, and fewer still have made the trip to the lake, which straddles the Arctic Circle.

headline: Help! My Constituents Are After Me!
text: Congressional Republicans are finding that constituents, like facts, are stubborn things.

headline: Strong Quake Strikes Southern Philippines, Killing at Least 6

headline: While Testy Fans Make a Stand, Knicks Do Not

headline: Jimmy Carter: From Peanuts to Solar Panels
text: Former President Jimmy Carter, 92, unveiled a solar energy project to help power his hometown. While President Trump has depicted himself as a champion of coal, Mr. Carter’s project aims to be a model for energy self-sufficiency and job growth.

headline: ‘Hell Hath No Fury Like a Woman Warned’

headline: Trying to Minimize the Misery of Mug Shots
text: The Haggler has a spotless criminal record. Of course, that is because the Haggler is a fictional construct, which means he has no wrists, and this makes him impossible to handcuff. Here we have a key difference between the Haggler and the bumbling nitwit whose name is affixed to this column. He has wrists. Has he ever been arrested? Nobody cares. And the Haggler doesn’t know because he and the nitwit are barely on speaking terms.

headline: Jimmy Carter Makes a Stand for Solar, Decades After the Cardigan Sweater
text: PLAINS, Ga. — The solar panels — 3,852 of them — shimmered above 10 acres of Jimmy Carter’s soil where peanuts and soybeans used to grow. The panels moved almost imperceptibly with the sun. And they could power more than half of this small town, from which Mr. Carter rose from obscurity to the presidency.

headline: Goats, Alpacas and (of Course) a Hen: Life on a Hobby Farm
text: Suzie Conn, a longtime advertising executive from Nashville, had never even seen an alpaca until moving to the country and showing up at a county fair.

headline: He’s ‘Little’ in the Film ‘Moonlight,’ but Big on the Dodgeball Court
text: LOS ANGELES — Alex R. Hibbert eyed a group of six children whipping red and yellow balls at one another in a large, reverberant pit made with trampoline floors and walls. He wanted in. But one player needed to get nailed by a ball and knocked out of the game first. He stood in line, his feet fidgeting, before bailing. He ran over to a nearby trampoline, pulled up his hoodie, crouched down and launched himself first upward and then backward into a flip.

headline: How a Top Model Also Became an Intersex Activist
text: One of the models starring in Alexander Wang’s show on Saturday on West 146th Street — a model who, with her I-dare-you blue-eyed stare and power stomp, is one of the most familiar faces on the runway — recently took on a new daytime gig. Not actress. Not brand ambassador.

headline: Move Over, Wikipedia. Dictionaries Are Hot Again.

headline: A Palm Beach Power Hostess Prepares for Trump’s Washington
text: Every presidential administration needs a grande dame to smooth relations between rival factions and serve as a bridge to society. In the 1970s and ’80s, Sally Quinn, then married to Benjamin C. Bradlee, executive editor of The Washington Post, was known for the high-I.Q. salons held at their Georgetown townhouse. Roughly a decade later, Georgette Mosbacher, a cosmetics executive and philanthropist, became Washington’s hostess supreme as a result of the round-table dinner parties she hosted with her then-husband, the oil tycoon turned commerce secretary Robert A. Mosbacher.

headline: More Women in Their 60s and 70s Are Having ‘Way Too Much Fun’ to Retire
text: Kay Abramowitz has been working, with a few breaks, since she was 14. Now 76, she is a partner in a law firm in Portland, Ore. — with no intention of stopping anytime soon. “Retirement or death is always on the horizon, but I have no plans,” she said. “I’m actually having way too much fun.”

headline: Lena Dunham and Judd Apatow on ‘Girls,’ ‘Geeks’ and Trolls
