headline: Are There Laws to Limit Excessive Light?
text: Q. I live in a small walk-up in Park Slope, Brooklyn. My bedroom windows face a six-story condominium. Those  windows are about 50 feet from six floor-to-ceiling glass walls in front of hallways. The building keeps fluorescent lights on in all six hallways all night long, creating a 60-foot-tall wall of light bright enough to make it look like the sun is shining into my bedroom at midnight. I hung light-blocking curtains and put black construction paper in my windows, which make the room dark enough to sleep. But is it legal for a building to create such an excessive amount of light pollution?

headline: How to Get the (Very Exclusive) Blue Mascara From Jason Wu
text: While the bright orange-red lip at Jason Wu’s fall/winter 2017 presentation was full of high-impact energy, it wasn’t the most compelling part of the beauty look. Instead, a subtle — but significant — flick of cobalt mascara generated quite a commotion backstage. “It’s a bit of Great Lash in Royal Blue,” said the makeup artist Yadim, name-checking the cult-classic shade that Maybelline discontinued in 2014 and makeup obsessives have been tracking ever since. Its appearance in Yadim’s kit, however, confirmed that the brand will, in fact, release it again: It will hit shelves this spring (May, to be exact).

headline: After Work, Down on the Farm
text: Remaining active and productive — and indulging a passion — are a few of the reasons more retirees are setting up small farms around the country.

headline: ‘A Sense of Dread’ for Civil Servants Shaken by Trump Transition

headline: A Star at the Apollo, Out of Its Spotlight
text: Every Sunday in February, we will feature and explore previously unpublished photographs from The New York Times’s archives, with a special focus on the 1960s. Revisit last year’s Unpublished Black History project, sign up for our Race/Related newsletter and share your own experiences with black history in the comments.

headline: Raymond Smullyan, Puzzle-Creating Logician, Dies at 97
text: Raymond Smullyan, whose merry, agile mind led him to be a musician, a magician, a mathematician and, most cunningly, a puzzle-creating logician, died on Monday in Hudson, N.Y. He was 97.

headline: Will We Lose the Doctor Who Would Stop the Next Flint?
text: FLINT, Mich. — Eighteen months ago, as a pediatrician here, I discovered that the untreated tap water corroding the city’s plumbing was poisoning our children with lead. State officials called my science faulty and accused me of creating hysteria. But I was right and persisted, and with brave parents, pastors, journalists and scientists demanded answers until this continuing public health disaster was finally acknowledged. An entire city, with about 10,000 young children, was unnecessarily exposed to lead, a neurotoxin that causes irreversible brain damage. The corrosive water also likely caused the deaths of a dozen people from Legionnaires’ disease. Flint remains traumatized.

headline: Gorsuch Not Easy to Pigeonhole on Gay Rights, Friends Say
text: WASHINGTON — Phil Berg was nervous as he prepared to tell Neil Gorsuch he was gay.

headline: In Neil Gorsuch’s Confirmations, Parsing the Meaning of ‘Yes’
text: WASHINGTON — When President Trump formally nominated Judge Neil M. Gorsuch to the Supreme Court, he boasted that Judge Gorsuch had been confirmed by the Senate to his current appeals court position by a unanimous vote more than decade ago.

headline: As Spring Training Nears, a Look at Baseball’s Window Treatment
text: It’s such an inviting word: window. Just look at those first three letters. Everyone wants to win, right? As spring training opens this week, in Florida and Arizona, there’s powerful symbolism in opening a window to a new season, drinking in the blue sky and dreaming of the best.

headline: Trump’s Economic Cabinet Is Mostly Bare. This Man Fills the Void.
text: A few weeks after the election, Gary Cohn, the president of Goldman Sachs, was summoned to Trump Tower for a discussion about the economy. It would be the first of many such meetings with President-elect Donald J. Trump.

headline: Yale Will Drop John Calhoun’s Name From Building
text: After a swelling tide of protests, the president of Yale announced on Saturday that the university would change the name of a residential college commemorating John C. Calhoun, the 19th-century white supremacist statesman from South Carolina. The college will be renamed for Grace Murray Hopper, a trailblazing computer scientist and Navy rear admiral who received a master’s degree and a doctorate from Yale.

headline: Judge, Jury, Executioner, President
text: You have certainly heard of Bowe Bergdahl — the American soldier captured by the Taliban after he left his post in Afghanistan, the subject of the second season of the podcast “Serial” and the recurring object, during the presidential campaign, of Donald J. Trump’s ire.

headline: Republicans Hold On to a Myth to Hold On to Power
text: Given the increased political power Republicans won in the last elections, from Washington to red-state legislatures, voters might expect the party to feel that the nation’s voting procedures are working quite well. Yet this is far from the case, as triumphant Republicans are using their enhanced clout to continue their campaign playing up the mythical threat that voter fraud abounds in the nation.

headline: Are Democrats Falling Into Trump’s Trap?
text: In one of many recent forums for the politicians vying to lead the Democratic National Committee — and, ideally, the party — out of the wilderness and into better times, the candidates were asked to distill the importance of fighting Donald Trump to 10 words or less.

headline: Can This Presidency Be Saved?
text: The peak of Donald Trump’s presidency, so far and perhaps forever, happened before he became the president. It was the deal he struck with Carrier, the Indiana air-conditioning company, to keep a factory open and jobs in the United States. No moment was so triumphantly Trumpian; nothing has gone as well for him since.

headline: How We Overcame Tyranny Before
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — From my home here, I look up at the immense mountain range of the Andes and my spirits are lifted. Since my childhood, these mountains have bestowed on me a sense of security and permanence sadly absent from my life, but in these troubling times, they afford me something else: an intimation of hope.

headline: Calvin Klein, Fendi and W Magazine Hold Parties for Fashion Week

headline: Calvin Klein, Fendi and W Magazine Hold Parties for Fashion Week
text: On Friday night, after the last runway show ended, the fashion flock headed to the South Street Seaport for a party celebrating F is For ... , a new app-slash-website from Fendi. Guests included Teyana Taylor, the floor-thumping star of Kanye West’s “Fade” music video. “Who doesn’t love Fendi? It’s always the greatest,” she said. “I have Wang tomorrow and then I finish my album.”

headline: Retirement Advice in the Trump Era
text: A federal judge in Texas did President Trump a favor last week. It came in a decision in a case filed by the financial industry against the Labor Department to overturn an Obama-era regulation called the “fiduciary rule,” which requires financial advisers to put their clients’ interests first when giving advice and selling investments for retirement accounts.

headline: Peaceful Protests Are Not a Crime
text: A bit of silver lining at the onset of the Trump administration has been the groundswell of activism by hundreds of thousands of Americans taking to the streets to face off against a president, and a Republican establishment, they see as reckless, divisive and destructive.

headline: Caitlyn Jenner’s Mission
text: Donald Trump’s inauguration was devoid of stars. Elton John said no. Justin Timberlake cried the president a river. The event was barren of A-listers. Except for one.

headline: Stephen Miller Is a ‘True Believer’ Behind Core Trump Policies

headline: Since When Is Being a Woman a Liberal Cause?
text: Who gets to define what it means to be pro-women? The left has staked its claim. The public face of resistance to President Trump began with a “women’s march.” An estimated three to five million turned out worldwide, brandishing signs like “Women’s Rights Are Not Up for Grabs” to deliver the message that to be a woman was to be against this president.

text: Nicole Broch Larsen is probably not discussing much about yardage and lines with her caddie this weekend at the Vic Open in Barwon Heads, Australia.

headline: Israel Bulldozes Democracy
text: HAIFA, Israel — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is expected to visit Washington this week to meet with President Trump, presumably to discuss the political philosophy they share: power through hate and fear. A government that bars refugees and Muslims from entering the United States has much in common with one that permits Israeli settlers to steal land from Palestinians, as a new law that Mr. Netanyahu’s coalition pushed through Parliament last week did.

headline: Bernhard Langer, 59, Is Still at the Top of His Game
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — There is a running joke among players on the PGA Tour Champions that their best chance of derailing the dominant Bernhard Langer is his risk of a back injury from hauling away all his trophies.

headline: Miles Cahn, Co-Founder of Coach Handbags, Dies at 95

headline: Trump Drops Defense of Obama Guidelines on Transgender Students
text: A nationwide injunction that has kept transgender students from using school bathrooms and other facilities that correspond with their gender identity will remain in place after the Trump administration decided not to challenge it in court. The move, announced Friday, ended an effort mounted by the Obama administration after the order was announced last year.

headline: Harvey Lichtenstein, Who Led Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Rebirth, Dies at 87

text: Caitlin Lee Dempsey and Robert Theodore Gambo were married Feb. 11 at the Harold Pratt House, an event space in New York. The Rev. Noel Clarke, a priest affiliated with CITI Ministries, led the ceremony.

headline: Lauren Perlgut, Benjamin Holzman
text: Lauren Beth Perlgut and Benjamin Ari Holzman were married Feb. 11 at Chelsea Piers in New York. Cantor Lisa Arbisser officiated.

headline: Jennifer Merrill, Dhruva Rajendra
text: Jennifer Laura Merrill and Dhruva Kumar Rajendra were married Feb. 6 at their home in Bethesda, Md., where Eric Koester, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Mary Cunningham, Matthew Ogren
text: Mary Kate Cunningham and Matthew Garland Ogren were married Feb. 11 at the McCormick Ranch Golf Club in Scottsdale, Ariz. The Rev. James Egbert, who was ordained by the Christian Universalist Association, officiated.

headline: Eileen Ahasic, Ian Bierig
text: Eileen Rose Ahasic and Ian Alexander Harper Bierig were married Feb. 11 at the Conrad B. Duberstein Courthouse in Brooklyn. Chief Judge Carla E. Craig of the bankruptcy division of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York officiated.

headline: Riva Margolis, Brett Hayden
text: Riva Rose Margolis and Dr. Brett Laurence Hayden were married Feb. 11 at Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in Manhattan. Rabbi Lester Bronstein led the ceremony.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: Grammys, ‘Girls’ and John Oliver
text: James Corden, he of the viral car-pool karaoke sessions, takes on the job of hosting this year’s Grammy Awards. On HBO, “Girls” returns for its final season, and “Last Week Tonight With John Oliver” is back for the first time since the week after the election.

headline: Meryl Streep Pledges to Stand Up to ‘Brownshirts’ in Tirade Against Trump
text: Meryl Streep, in a fiery speech criticizing President Trump on Saturday night, pledged to stand up against “brownshirts and bots” at a time when she and others are increasingly denouncing his administration’s policies and the president himself.

headline: A Test of Endurance for Drivers and Fans
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Twenty-four hours. One thousand four hundred forty minutes. Eighty-six thousand four hundred seconds.

headline: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Alec Baldwin and Melissa McCarthy Take On Trump and Sean Spicer
text: It took nearly an hour for Alec Baldwin, this weekend’s host of “Saturday Night Live” and its resident impersonator of President Trump, to don a certain familiar orange wig and assume the role that has occasionally infuriated the current real-life occupant of the Oval Office. In the meantime, “S.N.L.” took plenty of satirical shots at the Trump administration, starting with the return of Melissa McCarthy as the White House press secretary, Sean Spicer.

headline: Review: ‘S.N.L.’ Targets Trump Again, With a Hint of Exhaustion
text: If President Trump’s shock-and-awe attack on truth, decorum and liberal sensibilities is intended to bludgeon his opponents into submission, “Saturday Night Live” felt like his latest victim this weekend.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
text: 211 West 71st Street, No. 5C, Upper West Side

headline: How Beyoncé Could Make Grammy History Tonight
text: A look at Beyoncé’s Grammy Awards compared to the ceremony’s top winners since 1959.

headline: Trump’s Cabinet, Refugee Ban, Grammys: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: Adele Dominates the Grammys; Beyoncé Stops the Show
text: • Adele won album of the year for “25” and both record of the year and song of the year for “Hello.”

headline: After Gun Battle in Kashmir, Protests Turn Violent
text: NEW DELHI — Indian security forces in Kashmir engaged in an intense, 12-hour-long gun battle with militants that ended late Sunday morning, leaving four militants, two soldiers and one civilian dead, the authorities said. An additional civilian died after a protest.

headline: Lots of Eyeliner (and No After-Party) at Alexander Wang
text: “It’s a bit nocturnal,” said Diane Kendal of the onyx-rimmed eyeliner look she created for Alexander Wang’s fall/winter 2017 show, held at the RKO Hamilton Theater in Harlem. This kind of girl, she said, “has been out all night partying, having a good time.”

headline: World War II Bomb Removal in Greece Forces 72,000 From Homes
text: ATHENS — In Greece’s biggest peacetime evacuation ever, about 72,000 people left their homes in the city of Thessaloniki on Sunday as experts defused and removed a World War II bomb from below a gas station.

headline: 9 Million Desserts, for Gabriel, Michael, Alessandra and More
text: If the first step in Chuck Piekarski’s spice cake recipe sounds ordinary — “blend together margarine and sugar” until they are “well combined” — the quantities are not: 18 pounds of margarine and 120 cups of sugar. And, eventually, 18 quarts of eggs, 198 cups of all-purpose flour, 30 cups of vegetable oil, 16 cups of molasses, 63 tablespoons of baking powder and 15 quarts of milk.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Fashion Shows: Alexander Wang, Lacoste, Creatures of the Wind, Ryan Roche
text: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2017 collections that were presented in New York on Saturday.

headline: 52 Places to Go: Zermatt
text: Zermatt, Switzerland, offers spectacular views of the Matterhorn from every angle. Come hit the slopes in the Alps.

headline: Victoria Beckham: Fall 2017
text: Ms. Beckham shows her fall looks.

headline: Canada’s Conservatives Seek a Champion, and Redemption
text: OTTAWA — Canada’s Conservatives need a way back.

headline: ‘Fifty Shades Darker’ Submits to ‘Lego Batman’
text: LOS ANGELES — Three movies aimed at starkly different audiences made North American multiplexes hum over the weekend, as “The Lego Batman Movie” brought out families, “John Wick: Chapter Two” reeled in young men and the kinky sex thriller “Fifty Shades Darker” appealed to … well, you know who you are.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ and ‘Harry Potter’ Productions Try to Outwit Scalpers
text: LONDON — “Hamilton” and the new “Harry Potter” play are the hottest theatrical shows of the moment, with “Hamilton” outgrossing everything else on Broadway, and Harry, Hermione and Ron drawing hordes of muggles to London’s West End.

headline: Fashion’s Betsy DeVos Connection
text: It was an eventful week for the DeVos family of Grand Rapids, Mich. On Tuesday, Vice President Mike Pence cast the tiebreaking vote, confirming Betsy DeVos as the Trump administration’s Secretary of Education.

headline: Public School: Fall 2017
text: Dao-Yi Chow and Maxwell Osborne show their fall women’s collection.

headline: Immigration Raids Set Off Protests
text: A recent wave of immigration roundups prompted protests in several American cities, although officials at Immigration and Customs Enforcement said the crackdown that people were seeing did not represent an increased tempo.

headline: Top Opposition Leader in Cambodia Resigns as Election Nears
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — The embattled leader of Cambodia’s main opposition party abruptly quit on Saturday in the face of increasing government pressure, ceding a political stage he had occupied for more than two decades.

headline: Klimt Landscape ‘Bauerngarten’ Could Bring $45 Million
text: The auction house Sotheby’s has announced that “Bauerngarten,” a dazzling 1907 landscape painting by the Viennese modernist Gustav Klimt, will lead its Impressionist and Modern Art sale on March 1, in London. This marks the first time in more than two decades that the oil painting has been offered at auction, where it is expected to fetch in excess of $45 million.

headline: Donald Trump, North Korea, Kashmir: Your Morning Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Angela Merkel, Squeezed by Far Right, Now Faces a Rising Left
text: BERLIN — She is considered the indispensable European, yet one of the biggest questions looming over the Continent’s crucial elections this year is whether Germany still regards Angela Merkel as indispensable, too.

headline: Subway’s Slide in Performance Leaves Straphangers Fuming
text: Subway riders in New York City have become increasingly angry about the quality of service. Their fury is justified.

headline: Al Jarreau, Singer Who Spanned Jazz, Pop and R&B Worlds, Dies at 76
text: Al Jarreau, a versatile vocalist who sold millions of records and won a string of Grammys for his work in pop and R&B as well as his first love, jazz, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 76.

headline: Charges in Karina Vetrano’s Death Leave Suspect’s Parents Shaken
text: The retired schoolteacher hung the first poster board in his living room long ago, a record of achievements that filled him with pride: education certificates from his native Jamaica and New York City; a 1970s magazine article about new teachers that begins, “Richard Lewis: dashing, debonair, youthful and energetic.”

headline: Tome: Fall 2017
text: Ryan Lobo and Ramon Martin’s fall looks.

headline: Trump Sons Forge Ahead Without Father, Expanding and Navigating Conflicts
text: President Trump’s old office on the 26th floor of Trump Tower in Manhattan sits unoccupied now, unofficial storage space for the gathering trove of memorabilia that his two oldest sons say they hope will eventually be turned over to their father’s presidential library.

headline: ASAP Bari, Virgil Abloh and Jonathan Simkhai Party on Saturday Night of Fashion Week
text: Celebrations were held for Jonathan Simkhai’s lastest collection, and a sneaker collaboration between Nike and VLONE.

headline: Gypsy Sport: Fall 2017
text: Rio Uribe presents his latest designs.

headline: Netanyahu’s Meeting With Trump to Set Tone for U.S.-Israel Relations
text: JERUSALEM — As President Trump appeared to shift closer to the political center on several contentious policies on Israel, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu suggested on Sunday that it was unrealistic to expect their two countries to agree completely on all issues.

headline: World’s Diplomats, Seeking a Bridge to Trump, Look to Haley
text: UNITED NATIONS — The shock is gone. Panic is subsiding. Now, diplomats who represent the nations of the world are entering what one described as the third stage of grief: figuring out how to deal with President Trump.

headline: How to Get the Glowing Skin at Victoria Beckham
text: “It’s a simple start to the morning,” the lead makeup artist Pat McGrath said jokingly, backstage at Victoria Beckham’s fall/winter 2017 runway show this morning. She was referring to the “chic, sophisticated, intelligent” woman she channeled for this season’s beauty look, built upon a canvas of gorgeously luminescent skin. In reality, achieving that perfect base was far from simple.

headline: For Democrats, Being Out of Power Has Its Perks
text: BALTIMORE — There is something liberating about not being in charge.

headline: Williamstown Theater Fest Announces Lineup
text: The emerging playwright Jen Silverman’s “The Roommate” will kick off this summer’s Williamstown Theater Festival. The play pairs Jane Kaczmarek (“Malcolm in the Middle”) and S. Epatha Merkerson (“Law & Order”) as two women whose divergent backgrounds frustrate and illuminate when they move in together. (More of Ms. Silverman’s work can be seen starting Feb. 27, when her Brontë-inspired play “The Moors” makes its New York premiere at the Duke, on 42nd Street.)

headline: Activism Hits Even the Less Flashy Tech Companies
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As soon as President Trump signed his executive order on immigration, some of the biggest tech companies went quiet. Their executives did not sign legal briefs, brandish statements or dissent on Twitter. They strove for business as usual.

headline: Baby in a Box? Free Cardboard Bassinets Encourage Safe Sleeping
text: CAMDEN, N.J. — Jernica Quiñones, a mother of five, was the first parent in New Jersey to get her free baby box — a portable, low-tech bassinet made of laminated cardboard. But first, she had to take an online course about safe sleeping practices, which experts say can sharply reduce the chances of sudden infant death syndrome.

headline: China, the Party-Corporate Complex
text: There, they said it: China is not a market economy.

headline: Before You Take the Trip: How About a Virtual ‘Test Drive’?
text: From raising money for St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital to rolling out a new airline business class service, travel companies and tourism boards are increasingly turning to virtual reality to expand their reach and entice prospective clients.

text: Scenes from the Kate Spade and Tanya Taylor presentations on Day 2 of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Review: An Old Ballet Is Kissed Into New Life
text: MIAMI — Alexei Ratmansky’s latest ballet, “The Fairy’s Kiss,” feels like skillful, page-turning prose that opens in each scene into different forms of poetry. It’s also a completely clear piece of storytelling, carrying the audience through the four scenes of Igor Stravinsky’s fast-changing 1928 score “Le Baiser de la Fée.” (The music abounds in Stravinsky’s arrangements of items by Tchaikovsky, to whom it’s dedicated.)

headline: Off the Runway: New York Fashion Week Day 2
text: Our photographers captured the action backstage and between the shows on the second day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Review: A Tenor and a Soprano Make ‘I Puritani’ Gleam at the Met
text: There are serious downsides to the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of Bellini’s “I Puritani,” which opened on Friday. The company’s 1976 Sandro Sequi production is dustier-looking and duller than ever, and the conductor Maurizio Benini, a Met regular in the bel canto repertory, led a surprisingly limp and colorless performance of this lyrically sublime and elegant score.

headline: Review: Igor Levit, a Pianist for Polarizing Times
text: As we filed out after the pianist Igor Levit’s hypnotic Carnegie Hall debut recital on Friday evening, a friend made a little musical joke. “There wasn’t a note of mezzo-forte in there,” he said, meaning that Mr. Levit hadn’t much bothered with the space between very loud and very soft.

headline: Off the Runway: New York Fashion Week Day 4
text: Moments from the shows of TOME, Marcel Ostertag and Chloe Gosselin on the fourth day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: These Dogs Feel Like ‘Warm Bologna.’ Their Fans Say Bald Is Beautiful.
text: Anyone who has ever watched the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show knows how important it is for a dog to have a proper hairstyle.

headline: Off the Runway: New York Fashion Week Day 4
text: New York Fashion Week didn’t pause for winter weather. Our photographers captured the action backstage and between the shows.

headline: Neil Gaiman on His ‘Norse Mythology,’ in Which Odin Wants a Wall
text: Neil Gaiman was reading to a packed crowd from his new book of stories, “Norse Mythology,” on Thursday night at Town Hall, and he had 15 tales to choose from. He picked one called “The Master Builder.”

headline: Switzerland Votes to Ease Citizenship for Third-Generation Immigrants
text: GENEVA — The posters seen in several cities and provinces featured two very similar young women: both born in Switzerland, educated in Swiss schools, now in their 20s and working full time in Swiss jobs. They even share the given name Vanessa.

headline: In ‘Humans,’ if You Need a Marriage Counselor, See a Robot
text: “Humans,” the drama about human-robot relations co-produced by AMC and Channel 4 in Britain, aired its first season to modest notice in 2015. Then, like many technologies, it was eclipsed by a new model. When HBO’s “Westworld” — more cinematic, starring bigger names — followed in 2016, “Humans” became the Zune to the “Westworld” iPod.

headline: Into a Blue Evening Sky
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — I had two thoughts about today’s debut by Brent Sverdloff (with his collaborator, Michael Blake): The first was “Oh man, it’s another vowel progression” and the second one was “Hey, we haven’t seen one of these in a while. I can handle this frequency of vowel progression themes.”

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Feb. 13
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Head of Spain’s Far-Left Party Survives Leadership Challenge
text: MADRID — Pablo Iglesias, the head of Spain’s far-left Podemos Party, defeated a challenge in a leadership vote on Sunday, giving him a strong mandate to stick with the radical line that has made Podemos one of Europe’s main anti-establishment parties.

headline: The Grammys Red Carpet 2017
text: Check out what Adele, Ro James, Tinashe and more wore on the music industry’s biggest night. Updating with expected nominees like Beyoncé, Justin Bieber and Rihanna.

headline: The Grammys Red Carpet 2017
text: Check out what Adele, Rihanna, Jennifer Lopez and more wore on the music industry’s biggest night.

headline: Trump Responds to North Korean Missile Launch With Uncharacteristic Restraint
text: WASHINGTON — After North Korea threatened on New Year’s Day to test an intercontinental ballistic missile, Donald J. Trump, then president-elect, reacted with characteristic swagger. He vowed to stop the North from developing a nuclear weapon capable of hitting the United States. “It won’t happen!” he wrote on Twitter.

headline: Asian Tech Titans Take a Page From Trump’s Book
text: HONG KONG — In his book on deal making, President Trump offered a key piece of advice on getting what you want: Promise big.

headline: Turmoil at the National Security Council, From the Top Down
text: Over the weekend, The Times published this investigation into the agency that Michael T. Flynn was leading before he stepped down. Read our updated article on Mr. Flynn’s resignation.

headline: G.O.P. Lawmakers Like What They See in Trump. They Just Have to Squint.
text: WASHINGTON — Republican congressional aides have set their iPhones to flutter every time President Trump hurls a thunderbolt on Twitter. Senators nod politely at his false claims of mass voter fraud during private White House meetings. The congressional morning briefing literature now includes a rundown of overnight and early-morning social media missives from the commander in chief.

headline: With Everything About Trump, What’s a Designer to Do?
text: The night President and Mrs. Trump had dinner at Mar-a-Lago with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan and his wife, Akie Abe — after a nice round of golf and a garden tour, before North Korea necessitated an impromptu news conference — Alexander Wang dragged his audience up to the crumbling abandoned RKO Hamilton Theater on 146th Street in Harlem and jammed everyone into a standing-room-only area that once housed orchestra seats and now framed a raised runway.

headline: Migrating North, but to Mexico, Not the U.S.
text: SALTILLO, Mexico — Wendy no longer worries that when her sons leave the apartment in the morning, they may never make it to school. Memories of the gangs that haunted their lives in Honduras are slowly receding into the past.

headline: Republicans, Aiming to Kill Health Law, Also Work to Shore It Up
text: WASHINGTON — After denouncing the Affordable Care Act as an abomination for seven years, Republicans in Congress, working with the Trump administration, are urgently seeking ways to shore up health insurance marketplaces created by the law.

headline: ‘La La Land’ Wins Five Baftas, Continuing Its Oscar Momentum
text: LONDON — “La La Land” scooped up five EE British Academy Film Awards, or Baftas, on Sunday, adding some fuel to its fire as it marches toward what is viewed as a likely victory at the Oscars later this month.

headline: With More Muscle, Mets’ Syndergaard Envisions an Even Faster Fastball
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets’ success this season will hinge, in large part, on the health of several key players, particularly in the team’s starting rotation. In managing the return of pitchers Jacob deGrom, Matt Harvey, Steve Matz and Zack Wheeler from arm ailments, the Mets will undoubtedly rely on starter Noah Syndergaard, who had only minor problems last season and became the team’s workhorse.

headline: Lou Gehrig’s Fixer-Upper Awaits a Buyer for the Long Run
text: The Iron Horse had brass fixtures in his house. And galvanized steel wiring. He also had clapboard siding, parquet floors and a screened-in porch.

headline: Ex-Athlete’s Battle for Scholarship Upgrades: ‘I Feel Like I Helped My Brothers’
text: Shawne Alston’s family did not have much money when he was growing up in a rough part of Newport News, Va. He can remember some of his friends going to jail and some losing their lives to gang violence. Football was always Alston’s escape.

headline: Two Toasts From a Dusty Bottle
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Amazon’s Living Lab: Reimagining Retail on Seattle Streets
text: SEATTLE — On a busy stretch of road in this city’s Ballard neighborhood, a curious new grocery store is taking shape — and so begins another effort by Amazon to use the residents of its hometown as guinea pigs.

headline: Sand Between Their Toes, and Blades on Their Feet
text: GEORGE TOWN, Cayman Islands — After trading long Canadian winters for the perpetual summer of this luxurious Caribbean tax haven, Bill Messer was content to enjoy the soft sands and warm waters of island living. The only thing he really missed was hockey.

headline: When a Pillar of the Fourth Estate Rests on a Trump-Murdoch Axis
text: The ties that bind the most powerful media mogul in the world to the leader of the free world just keep getting stronger. Or, more precisely, we keep learning just how strong they are.

headline: U.S. Soccer Looks to Premier League for a Performance Boost
text: U.S. Soccer is continuing a significant overhaul of its developmental program with the hiring of the top sports scientist in England’s Premier League, who will join the federation this month as its director of high performance.

headline: Latrell Sprewell Visits. Minds Boggle. Knicks Win.
text: If the Knicks had hoped that Sunday afternoon’s game against the San Antonio Spurs would be a return to a semblance of normalcy, that notion did not last long.

headline: Police Chiefs Say Trump’s Law Enforcement Priorities Are Out of Step
text: Not surprisingly, President Trump’s approach to crime, which began to take shape in a series of moves last week, generated swift criticism from liberals and civil rights groups.

headline: As Japan Ages, Menus Adapt to Finding the Gourmet in Purées
text: YOKOHAMA, Japan — The 94-year-old man had come for lunch at a Chinese restaurant, and he was determined to make the most of his squid and leek stir-fry.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Since they just opened up the Second Avenue subway, maybe they could get some funding over here on the C train.”

headline: In the Face of Weighty Problems, Trump Focuses on Squabbles
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — The morning after North Korea launched a ballistic missile into the sea, apparently to test President Trump’s resolve in his first days in office, the new commander in chief wanted to make one thing very clear to the world: Mark Cuban, the billionaire Dallas Mavericks owner, was not smart enough to have his job.

headline: Anger and Mistrust Fuel Unabated Protests in Romania
text: BUCHAREST, Romania — Exactly one week after the largest protests in a quarter of a century rocked Romania, an estimated 70,000 demonstrators filled the square outside the main government building in Bucharest on Sunday evening, determined to show those in power that the crisis was far from over.

headline: Trudeau and Trump Are to Meet, and Yellen Will Address Congress
text: Here’s a look at what’s coming up this week.

headline: Immigration Agents Arrest 600 People Across U.S. in One Week
text: Federal immigration officials arrested more than 600 people across at least 11 states last week, detaining 40 people in the New York City area, law enforcement officials said on Sunday.

headline: How the Election Shaped a Fashion Collection
text: The political events of 2016 pushed Joseph Altuzarra toward Renaissance painting and a “protected” feeling for his fall 2017 collection. And, he said, a move into the Woolworth Building was a move into adulthood.

headline: Joseph Altuzarra Is Craving a Kind of Armor
text: In the latest installment of our series that goes inside the private working worlds of designers, Joseph Altuzarra reveals what was behind his latest collection, why he needs a door and why Tom Ford made him want to be a designer. And those are just the outtakes that didn’t make it into the video. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Prabal Gurung: Fall 2017
text: Mr. Gurung’s fall designs.

headline: Slovene Ilka Stuhec Wins Women’s Downhill Title at Alpine Ski World Championships
text: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland — Ilka Stuhec has proved she can carry the torch for Slovene Alpine skiing, winning a world downhill title and succeeding the recently retired Tina Maze, who accomplished the same for Slovenia two seasons ago.

headline: Review: A Hairy Visionary Who Has the Ruler’s Ear
text: He was a drunk, a manipulator and a serial seducer. His influence may have hastened regime change. Apparently, he smelled of goats. But at least he didn’t have a seat on the National Security Council, right?

headline: Report Rebuts Russia’s Claims of Restraint in Syrian Bombing Campaign
text: WASHINGTON — Russian military officials have vociferously denied that their airstrikes have killed civilians in Syria, going so far as to say that eyewitness accounts that a major hospital was bombed last year in the brutal fight to retake Aleppo were mere fabrications.

headline: ‘Homeland,’ Season 6, Episode 4: A Warning to All Young Men — Avoid Carrie
text: So it looks like we’re done with Sekou. Is anyone really surprised?

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Season 7, Episode 9: Rick Makes Friends, Mows Zombies
text: After eight weeks of subjugation by the Saviors, Alexandria began its rebound on Sunday’s “Walking Dead,” as Rick resumed his hero’s mantle and embarked on a campaign of coalition building, explosives commandeering, zombie mowing and enigmatic smiling.

headline: Grammys Fashion 2017, Weird as Usual
text: The fashion on the Grammys red carpet always gets a little weird. Remember Margaret Cho’s sheer peacock dress, Jennifer Lopez’s low-low-low-cut Versace dress (which, in retrospect, actually seems almost demure), and Nicki Minaj’s Little Red Riding Hood-like cape?

headline: The Rot in French Politics
text: A little over two weeks ago, it looked like François Fillon, the nominee of the conservative Les Républicains party, was set to win the French presidency. Then, revelations  late last month in the satirical weekly Le Canard Enchaîné that Mr. Fillon’s wife and children were on the public payroll, receiving payments totaling nearly $1 million, sent his poll ratings plunging.

headline: In Japan, Another Quarter of Modest Growth Represents a Victory
text: TOKYO — Japan extended its yearlong streak of modest economic growth in the last three months of 2016, data showed on Monday.

headline: Knicks End Four-Game Skid With Uplifting Win Over Spurs
text: Before facing the Knicks at Madison Square Garden on Sunday afternoon, Spurs Coach Gregg Popovich was asked, in a long-winded way, his opinion of the critical Twitter posts that the Knicks president Phil Jackson had made about Carmelo Anthony, the team’s star player.

headline: Fashion Week Briefing: Day 4
text: The fourth day of Fashion Week kicked off with a show from former Spice Girl Victoria Beckham, who seemed to have powerful women on her mind. Public School’s New York born and bred designers, Dao-Yi Chow and Maxwell Osborne, referenced politics in their show, and Diane von Furstenberg offered an affordable and animal-friendly option for winter bundling.  And, last but not least, there was an appearance by someone who has kept a low profile since the election: Huma Abedin.

headline: Trump Friend Suggests Reince Priebus Is in Over His Head
text: WASHINGTON — A longtime friend of President Trump’s who met with him this weekend in Florida issued a public rebuke of the president’s chief of staff on Sunday, blaming him for the botched rollout of Mr. Trump’s targeted travel ban and saying the early chaos in the White House may not ease until he departs.

headline: More Unusual (and Definitely Special) Engagement Rings
text: This month, inspired by Marianne Rohrlich’s article about unusual engagement rings, we asked readers to submit images of their own special engagement rings.  Here is a selection of rings that range from simple to extravagant, but all  rich in sentimental value.

headline: Flood Risk Near Oroville Dam Causes Thousands to Evacuate in California
text: The authorities in Northern California raced to evacuate tens of thousands of people on Sunday night in fear of the possible failure of an emergency spillway at the Oroville Dam.

headline: Beyoncé’s and Adele’s Grammy Speeches: Transcripts
text: Beyoncé did not utter the words “President Trump” on Sunday as she accepted the Grammy for best urban contemporary album for “Lemonade,” but her powerful statement about the need for positive depictions of black lives spoke to the current political moment. Here is her full speech:

headline: For Top Pinball Competitors, Jitters Only Help
text: The best pinball players in New York State had been competing all afternoon on Saturday, and now it was down to the last few silver balls, in a title match between the Storm and Zen, two dominant players whose styles could not have been more different.

headline: Adele Restarts George Michael Grammy Tribute After Flub
text: In a jaw-dropping live television moment at the Grammy Awards on Sunday, Adele stopped a commemorative performance for the late George Michael mid-song with an f-bomb after realizing that her vocals were off key.

headline: Altuzarra: Fall 2017
text: Joseph Altuzarra shows his fall looks.

headline: Near Nudity and Modesty Mix at Grammys
text: Forgoing trousers has been a dubious mark of pop feminist empowerment at least since Madonna’s “Who’s That Girl” tour 30 years ago, but at the 59th Grammy Awards, several performers decided this wasn’t enough and that they must lose their shirts.

headline: Beyoncé, Katy Perry and A Tribe Called Quest Bring Politics to the Grammys
text: For most of the 59th annual Grammy Awards on Sunday night, political statements were merely implied or hinted at. Then came A Tribe Called Quest.

headline: Adele, Syria, Hamburg: Your Monday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Champions League, Meant to Dazzle, Settles for ‘You Again?’
text: MANCHESTER, England — These are the games that are supposed to make the mouth water. When the Champions League resumes this week after its winter hiatus, it will do so with a slate of matches speckled with stardust.

headline: North Korea Claims Progress on Long-Range Goal With Missile Test
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea claimed on Monday that it had successfully tested a new type of nuclear-capable missile, one that uses a solid-fuel technology that American experts say will make it easier for the country to hide its arsenal underground and roll its missiles out for quick launch.

headline: Corrections: February 13, 2017
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘The Young Pope’ and ‘The New Celebrity Apprentice’
text: It’s the night of two season finales. “The Young Pope,” Paolo Sorrentino’s campy and operatic drama starring Jude Law, wraps up its limited run on HBO. And Matt Iseman faces off against Boy George in the final round of “The New Celebrity Apprentice,” hosted by Arnold Schwarzenegger.

headline: Word + Quiz: queue
John Oliver Hatches a Plan to Reach Trump Where He Watches
text: John Oliver kicked off his fourth season on HBO on Sunday night with 25 minutes of predictable outrage that built to five spectacular minutes of brashly original guerrilla warfare.

headline: Where Do You Find the Meanings of Unfamiliar Words?
text: From the print edition of a dictionary to its online version, to a Google search to asking your favorite wordsmith or using context to make a reasonable guess, it’s clear that there are many ways to learn the meaning of a new word.

headline: Haunted by Student Debt Past Age 50
text: The experience of being crushed by student debt is no longer limited to the young. New federal data shows millions of Americans who are retired or nearing retirement face this burden, as well as the possibility of having their Social Security benefits garnished to make payments.

headline: The Power of Disruption
text: The Trump resistance movement is stretching its wings, engaging its muscles and feeling its power. It is large and strong and tough. It has moved past debilitating grief and into righteous anger, assiduous organization and pressing activism.

headline: Australia’s Grim Toll in the Church’s Sex Abuse Scandal
text: The global scale of the Catholic clergy’s sexual abuse scandal becomes harder for the Vatican to deny with each shocking national inquiry. The latest, from Australian government investigators, found that from 1980 to 2015 there were 4,444 victims of abuse and at least 1,880 suspected to be abusers, most of them priests and religious brothers.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Ignorance Is Strength
text: When I travel to Asia, I’m fairly often met at the airport by someone holding a sign reading “Mr. Paul.” Why? In much of Asia, names are given family first, personal second — at home, the prime minister of Japan is referred to as Abe Shinzo. And the mistake is completely forgivable when it’s made by a taxi driver picking up a professor.

headline: LSD to Cure Depression? Not So Fast
text: Psychedelics, the fabled enlightenment drugs of the ’60s, are making a comeback — this time as medical treatment.

headline: A Rare Republican Call to Climate Action
text: The most important thing about a carbon tax plan proposed last week may be the people behind it: prominent Republicans like James Baker III, George Shultz and Henry Paulson Jr. Their endorsement of the idea, variations of which have been suggested before, may be a breakthrough for a party that has closed its eyes to the perils of man-made climate change and done everything in its power to thwart efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Unraveling Love Stories
text: Nearly everyone I know my age is in crisis. Apparently, it comes with midlife. Luis, who had dedicated himself for years to saving a destitute relationship, acting like an emotional pack animal by taking on more and more weight of his partner’s pathologies, learned that the person sleeping next to him every night was texting in the darkness to someone else. His sudden awakening shattered his sense of reality. Carrying his partner’s burdens, far from simply being a sign of his kindheartedness, had actually facilitated the years of unhappiness on both ends, and the turning of backs in bed.

headline: The Pictures Generation
text: Behind the scenes of T magazine’s Pictures Generation photo shoot, as Douglas Crimp, Robert Longo and Laurie Simmons remember the '80s.

headline: The Pictures Generation’s Greatest Hits
text: A selection of works by the group of New York artists who first came to prominence in the early ’80s.

headline: The Faces of the Pictures Generation
text: From Cindy Sherman and Robert Longo to David Salle and Laurie Simmons, portraits of 17 of the movement’s key artist, critics and gallerists.

headline: These ’80s Artists Are More Important Than Ever
text: Images and technological media now pervade every minute of our lives so thoroughly that much of what passes for reality is indistinguishable from its representation. The urban environment is a cloaca of hypnotic, animated signage, sounds and image streams that follow us into taxicabs and hospital waiting rooms, and in turn, any banality, from a misspelled street sign to a funny advertisement, is considered suitable to become an image on social media.

headline: At Kochi Biennale, Art Imitating Death: An Artist at Work
text: The Kochi-Muziris Biennale is one of the largest exhibitions of contemporary art in India. Follow Yardena Kurulkar as she installs her work, “The Dance of Death.”

text: On Saturday, two and a half days before his first show in New York, the German designer Philipp Plein sat behind a long table crowded with Starbucks coffee cups, Red Bull cans and Atkins energy bars in a rented office space on Madison Avenue and 55th Street.

headline: Scenes From Mar-a-Lago as Trump and Abe Get News About North Korea
text: Photographs posted on Facebook show the prime minister of Japan, Shinzo Abe, and the president of the United States as they scrambled to respond to a North Korean ballistic missile test.

headline: After Knee Replacement Surgery, Skiing the Colorado Rockies
text: I negotiated the chairlift to the top of Snowmass without incident on a perfect blue-sky day in the Colorado Rockies. So far, so good. I took as deep a breath as a person can at 11,000 feet, pointed my skis downhill and made my first turn in the fluffy morning snow — on a brand-new titanium-and-plastic left knee.

headline: For Religious Conservatives, Success and Access at the Trump White House
text: WASHINGTON — The people who filled the pews of St. John’s Episcopal Church for a private service on the morning of the inauguration were a testament to the ascendancy of the religious right in Donald J. Trump’s Washington: James Dobson, the founder of Focus on the Family; Tony Perkins, the president of the Family Research Council; James Robison, the Christian television preacher.

headline: Emmanuel Macron Steps Into France’s Political Void
text: PARIS — Insults and rumors keep coming: His speeches are too long and full of feel-good banalities. He does not have a real program. His time in government was a failure. He is secretly gay. He is developing a personality cult. He favors capitalism, and besides, he is too young.

headline: Profitable Pickups May Be in Cross Hairs of Trump Border Tax
text: DETROIT — There are many reasons for the steady success of the three major American automakers in recent years, but none are bigger than the surging sales of full-size pickup trucks.

headline: A Liberal Wanted to Agitate Ole Miss From Inside. He’s Succeeding.
text: OXFORD, Miss. — Allen Coon, perhaps the most reviled student at the University of Mississippi, was walking to his public policy class at the Trent Lott Leadership Institute on a recent weekday morning, sporting a red faux Trump cap emblazoned with the message MAKE AMERICA NATIVE AGAIN.

headline: Growth Secrets of the Hydra
text: The tiny hydra, a relative of jellyfish and a favorite in school biology labs, can regrow a whole animal from a piece, partly because even small remnants contain part of a protein scaffold that guides development.

headline: How a Little Bit of Hydra Regrows a Whole Animal
text: The hydra is a favorite subject of middle school science. It is a fearsome-looking tentacled predator, but it is tiny — less than a half inch — and lives in ponds. You can collect or buy hydras and the tiny crustaceans they eat, then watch the capture under a dissecting microscope. Hydras, like jellyfish, have stinging cells in their tentacles.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Feb. 13, 2017
text: Note: Because many schools are off on Feb. 20 for Presidents’ Day, our next What’s Going On in This Picture? will take place on Feb. 27.

headline: The Puzzling Popularity of Back Surgery in Certain Regions
text: You might think that once drugs, devices and medical procedures are shown to be effective, they quickly become available. You might also think that those shown not to work as well as alternatives are immediately discarded.

headline: The World’s Best Photo?
text: A dramatic image of the assassination of Russia’s ambassador to Turkey was named the Photo of the Year in the 2017 World Press Photo contest. The photo was taken in December during a routine assignment at a photo exhibition that Burhan Ozbilici, an Associated Press photographer, decided to attend at the last moment simply because it was on his way home. He arrived during Ambassador Andrey G. Karlov’s speech, and within moments a 22-year-old off-duty police officer, Mevlut Mert Altintas, opened fire. Although Mr. Ozbilici was no more than 15 feet from the gunman, he did not run.

headline: The World’s Best Photo?
text: The top prize in the World Press Photo contest went to a dramatic image of the assassination of Russia’s ambassador to Turkey. Here are the top photos in various categories.

headline: Why Weight Loss Surgery Works When Diets Don’t
text: “Bariatric surgery is probably the most effective intervention we have in health care,” says Laurie K. Twells, a clinical epidemiologist at Memorial University of Newfoundland. She bases this bold claim on her experience with seriously obese patients and a detailed analysis of the best studies yet done showing weight-loss surgery’s ability to reverse the often devastating effects of being extremely overweight on health and quality of life.

text: SYDNEY, Australia — An Islamic State fighter who posted a photo of a beheaded Syrian soldier online has become the first dual national to be stripped of his Australian citizenship under antiterrorism laws, according to local news reports.

headline: What Does ‘Dress Like a Woman’ Mean? Designers Tackle the Question
text: What does it really mean to “dress like a woman”? Social media recently took it upon itself to answer that question, after a brief flurry of rumors about a possible White House dress code. At the Grammys, so did Beyoncé, who apparently decided it meant looking like the golden goddess of fecundity. Now designers are having their turn. It is, after all, a question that lies at the heart of fashion, and that they, at least theoretically, are supposed to be asking themselves every season.

text: Standing outside the Erasmus Hall High School campus in the Flatbush neighborhood of Brooklyn, Mario Rivera, 17, acknowledged he did not know much about the deteriorating old white building that sits in the middle. “That’s where the school started,” Mr. Rivera said with a shrug.

headline: Sharp Rise Reported in Older Americans’ Use of Multiple Psychotropic Drugs
text: The number of retirement-age Americans taking at least three psychiatric drugs more than doubled between 2004 and 2013, even though almost half of them had no mental health diagnosis on record, researchers reported on Monday.

headline: Syria Used Chlorine Bombs Systematically in Aleppo, Report Says
text: Syrian military helicopters systematically dumped canisters of chlorine gas, a banned weapon, on residential areas of Aleppo at least eight times late last year in the final weeks of the battle to retake the city from rebels, Human Rights Watch said in a detailed study released Monday.

The move could further isolate the impoverished Palestinian coastal enclave and portend a more aggressive stance against Israel.

headline: Throwing Away a Legal Career for $310,000
text: Would you sell your career for $310,000? It appears that Jeffrey A. Wertkin may have tried to do just that by passing a copy of a sealed whistle-blower complaint against a Silicon Valley company to one of its employees in exchange for that amount.

headline: Dairy-Free Vegan Chocolates in Chelsea
text: Pamela Elizabeth (far right), who established her group of vegan restaurants and cafes in 2005, had a vegan chocolate and pastry shop in Chelsea for a few years. She closed it in 2013 because her chocolate maker left, and it has taken her until now to find another. Damion Badalamenti (near right) is now fashioning dairy-free truffles, caramels, bonbons and other confections for Ms. Elizabeth’s revived and smartly redecorated shop, which opened Tuesday. Mr. Badalamenti, who is not vegan, said that combining chocolate with nut milks instead of dairy is tricky business. He is using chocolate from Valrhona from France and Felchlin from Switzerland for the handmade confections. The shop also sells pastries and drinks: Cocoa V Chocolat, 174 Ninth Avenue (21st Street), cocoav.com.

headline: A Finishing Salt From the North Atlantic
text: Alda the mermaid, the symbol of this Nordur Salt and guardian of the supply, sounds straight out of the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of Dvorak’s “Rusalka,” about a water nymph. The coarse, flaky salt from Iceland is made by evaporating seawater. While much of the geothermal manufacturing process has been updated since 1753, the salt is still raked by hand. Use it as a finishing salt, dusted on potatoes, a salad or poached eggs just before serving: Nordur Arctic Sea Salt Flakes, $11.99 for 8.8 ounces, salttraders.com.

headline: The Crowler: An Aluminum Answer to the Growler
text: The typical method for taking draft beer home from a bar, brewery or store is a reusable 64-ounce glass growler jug. But the growler has flaws, which has led Oskar Blues Brewery in Longmont, Colo., to develop the Crowler, a 32-ounce can into which keg beer is dispensed. The can is sealed, and you’re good to go. Why is the Crowler better than a growler? Ted Kenny, the owner of Top Hops Beer Shop on the Lower East Side, which recently installed a Crowler machine, said it’s lighter to carry, won’t break, can be taken on a boat, is impervious to air and light, and will keep the beer fresh far longer than the 24-hour limit you get with a jug. The cans can be used only once, but they are recyclable: Top Hops Beer Shop, 94 Orchard Street (Delancey Street), 212-254-4677, tophops.com.

headline: Grammy Awards Gain About 1 Million More Viewers This Year
text: Viewership for the Grammy Awards rose on Sunday night, with an average of about 26 million viewers, about a million more than last year’s ceremony, according to Nielsen.

headline: Learn How to Make Rye Bread and Cinnamon Twists
text: A series of classes from Meyers Bageri, the baker behind the pastries at Great Northern Food Hall and a shop in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, will cover its specialties: Scandinavian sourdough rye and wheat breads and the cinnamon breakfast pastries called kanelsnurrer. The two-and-a-half-hour classes are being taught through the end of April in the bakery’s commissary: Baking classes, $110 and a $4.84 fee, Feb. 25 through April 30 at Meyers Bageri Commissary, 38-40 10th Street (40th Avenue), Long Island City, Queens, brownpapertickets.com (search: bageri).

headline: The Modern Love Podcast: Valentine’s Day Edition
text: For Valentine’s Day, we stitched together three stories about love. First, hear Colin Farrell read Gary Presley’s essay about a quadriplegic man who finds love with a female attendant, “Would My Heart Outrun Its Pursuer?” Then, Gillian Jacobs reads Mandy Len Catron’s essay “To Fall in Love With Anyone, Do This,” also known as the most popular Modern Love column of all time. And finally, listen as Tony Hale tells Steve Friedman’s story of rejection, “Just Friends? Let Me Read Between the Lines.”

headline: Which Dystopian Novel Got It Right: Orwell’s ‘1984’ or Huxley’s ‘Brave New World’?
text: Charles McGrath The totalitarian rulers in Huxley’s book give their citizens exactly what they think they want. TWO months ago I would have said that not only is “Brave New World” a livelier, more entertaining book than “1984,” it’s also a more prescient one. Orwell didn’t really have much feel for the future, which to his mind was just another version of the present. His imagined London is merely a drabber, more joyless version of the city, still recovering from the Blitz, where he was living in the mid-1940s, just before beginning the novel. The main technological advancement there is the two-way telescreen, essentially an electronic peephole.

headline: Mob Kills Eloped Lovers After Storming Afghan Police Station
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An armed mob that included relatives of a young woman who had eloped with her lover stormed a police station holding the couple in eastern Afghanistan over the weekend, then dragged the lovers off and killed them, officials and witnesses said.

headline: Trump Speaks With Nigeria’s President, Who Hasn’t Been Seen in Weeks

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 13 at Protest in Lahore, Pakistan
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — At least 13 people were killed, including six police officers, by a suicide bomber on Monday during a protest by hundreds of pharmacists in downtown Lahore, in eastern Pakistan, officials said. The attack wounded 108 people, 13 of them critically.

headline: Children Cook This Presidents’ Day Weekend
text: The New York Botanical Garden will hold informal classes about edible plants, cooking demonstrations with chefs, and tastings for children for Presidents’ Day weekend. There will be workshops and cooking demonstrations on the hour to showcase recipes like carrot rice, sweet potato and squash lasagna, and lemony chicken soup, with chefs including Matt Abdoo of Pig Bleecker: Culinary Kids Weekend, Feb. 18 to 20, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.: adults, $25, those 65 and older and students, $22, children 2 to 12, $10, New York Botanical Garden, nybg.org.

headline: Chupacabra Gets His Revenge, on a Tortilla Chip
text: Heidi’s Salsa, from California, sells three versions of the chunky tomato dip that are hard to distinguish from appearance alone. On the palate, they tell a different story. The Original Mild, based on a family recipe, is just that, with a modest kick in the finish and a texture that would welcome pasta as well as tacos. The Happy Medium is almost as forceful as the hot Chupacabra’s Revenge, which also has more complexity: Heidi’s Salsa, $12 for two, $18 for three 16-ounce jars, heidissalsa.com; also sold at Target stores and in New York City at Morton Williams.

headline: ABCV
text: The chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten is preparing to open his first all-vegetarian restaurant.

headline: A Peek at ABCV, a Top Chef’s First Vegetarian Restaurant
text: Who knew that vegetables would take this long to prepare? After several years of talk and planning, the chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten is preparing to open his first all-vegetarian restaurant, ABCV, by the end of the month.

headline: Make the Grammys More Like the Oscars
text: Anybody who tells you that Adele’s “Hello” or Beyoncé’s “Lemonade” aren’t masterpieces of human culture is not your friend. But those who cite the huge hitmakers — Ariana Grande, Rihanna, Demi Lovato — on the list of Grammy nominees, and note that the top-echelon awards go to artists who are widely known have a point. In these times, an awards show broadcast focused almost entirely on artists who already make a ton of money is not smart business.

headline: Carolina Herrera Puts a Bow on It
text: It has been an eventful two months for Carolina Herrera. First there was that nasty lawsuit against Oscar de la Renta wherein it transpired that her former chief executive had hired a former ODLR designer to be her heir in waiting without telling her, a situation that did not end well for anyone involved. (The designer returned to her previous place of employ, the chief executive left, and dirty laundry was seen by all.) Then there was the Ivanka Trump inaugural ball gown, a fairy-tale confection that cast Mrs. Herrera into the eye of the political storm.

headline: The Artist Making — and Dating — Clay Men
text: At a wedding once, the artist Mary Stephenson explained to another guest that she had been single for years. “What a waste,” was the stranger’s reply. And just like that, Stephenson was inspired to create her irreverent “My Man” series. Far from being a rage against spinsterhood, her lighthearted series consists of works of similar construction: Stephenson photographed alongside the “boyfriends” she creates, against painterly tableaus of romantic settings. “This is a playful way of acting out my anticipated relationships rather than just internalizing them,” the 28-year-old explains from her studio in Dalston, East London, which resembles the backstage of a theater thanks to piles of props, costumes and scenery.

headline: You May Be ‘The Young Pope,’ but You’re No Francis
text: HBO’s “The Young Pope” depicts the dashing and fictitious Pope Pius XIII as a ruthless knife fighter willing to cut down anyone in his path back to a purer church. Yet as I binge-watched the first season in my Washington basement, after weeks of watching real-life Vatican power politics in Rome, I couldn’t help thinking that the Young Pope has nothing on the Old Pope.

headline: In Shadow of California Dam, Water Turns From Wish to Woe
text: OROVILLE, Calif. — It wasn’t so long ago that residents here had to drag their houseboats into a dusty field from the barren banks of Lake Oroville, which had almost no water left to keep them afloat.

headline: Six Questions for Cate Blanchett
text: The title of “The Present,” now playing on Broadway, is a clever one. The play takes place at a summer house in Russia on the occasion of a 40th birthday, and its props include a few physical gifts — notably, a chess set and an antique gun. (The play is a Chekhov adaptation, so yes, both get used before the final curtain falls.) But it’s also concerned with the specters raised by “the present” as a concept, particularly in a group of friends with years of history between them: How does the past of each relationship impact how we might feel about it now? How much can we ever depend on the future?

headline: Allergan’s Deal for Fat-Freezing Treatment Shows Spending for Growth
text: Allergan has added ice and a slice to its M&A cocktail. The drug company is paying just under $2.5 billion for Zeltiq Aesthetics and its diet-avoiding, fat-freezing technology. It sounds like a wackier play than the dozen deals Allergan struck last year. But people pay cash for the treatment, making it less speculative than other acquisitions, such as gene therapy.

headline: How to Get the Fresh-Eyed Look From Proenza Schouler

(Makeup was otherwise minimal — and hair was center-parted to play up each model’s own natural texture.)

But there’s a thread that runs through films like “Scottsboro: An American Tragedy” (which won an Emmy and was nominated for a best-documentary Oscar), “My Lai” and the recent “Oklahoma City”: an interest in moments when the promise of America is violently betrayed.

headline: ‘More Artists Are Going to Boycott’: The Grammys Face Fallout After Fraught Awards
text: Before the 59th annual Grammy Awards on Sunday, the music industry murmured about what it might mean for Adele to once again sweep the top awards, leaving Beyoncé snubbed in the major categories and with her third loss for album of the year. Having long faced accusations that the Grammys overlook young, progressive black artists — the last black woman to win album of the year was Lauryn Hill in 1999 — the Recording Academy faced a potential backlash for going all-in on a white, traditionalist choice like Adele.

headline: The Jean-Michel Basquiat You Haven’t Seen

And increasingly, they happen onstage — in fictional tragedies and verbatim dramas that explore the psychology of the shooters and the consequences for the affected individuals and communities.

headline: Lt. Gen. Harold Moore, Whose Vietnam Heroism Was Depicted in Film, Dies at 94
text: Lt. Gen. Harold G. Moore, whose fortitude saved most of his outnumbered battalion in 1965 in the first major battle between American and North Vietnamese troops — exploits immortalized in a book and a movie starring Mel Gibson — died on Friday at his home in Auburn, Ala. He was 94.

headline: ‘Like 9/11 All Over Again’: Canadians Grow Fearful of Crossing the Border

People cross all the time to work, shop, visit a gallery, go to a show or a game. Taxis regularly make the trip, and there’s even a Windsor city bus route through the tunnel.

headline: Double Triumph for Patricia Hearst’s Bulldogs at Westminster
text: As the French bulldogs entered the ring on Monday afternoon, Patricia Hearst Shaw, looking as unassuming as the average spectator, took a seat in the front row of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. Dressed casually in a striped top and black pants, she did not seem to fit the part of the well-heeled women of Westminster or its dog-sweater-wearing fanciers. On the edge of a green-carpeted show ring, she teetered between anonymity and renown.

headline: Archenemy of Bugs Bunny
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — We have a debut today, and I discovered quite accidentally that the constructor, Daniel Larsen, is not only a mere 13 years old, but has established a record for being the youngest person to have a crossword published in The New York Times. I discovered this when I wrote to him requesting notes, and the response came from an email account with a different name. That account belongs to the young Mr. Larsen’s father, presumably because today’s constructor is not old enough to have one of his own yet.

headline: Review: In ‘Life According to Saki,’ Whistling a Perversely Happy Tune
text: A chipper young troupe out of Britain is pulling sunshine from the dark in “Life According to Saki,” a bouncy adaptation of the elegantly macabre short stories of its title character. A hit at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe last year, this brisk entertainment bears the same relation to its source material as the 1964 Disney film “Mary Poppins” did to the novels that inspired it.

headline: Corruption Scandals With Brazilian Roots Cascade Across Latin America
text: LIMA, Peru — A former Peruvian president is a fugitive, charged with taking bribes. In Colombia, prosecutors say its president’s re-election campaign accepted dirty money. And intelligence agents in Venezuela arrested journalists and researchers looking into scandals there.

text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The Trump administration announced sanctions against Venezuela’s vice president on Monday, calling him a drug “kingpin” in its first moves against the country’s leftist government, which President Trump railed against during his campaign.

headline: South Korea’s Olympian Winter Moment
text: Emerging from the warmth of her car, Jung Sang-mi watched her husband trudge up a snowy hill, red sled in hand, as their 5-year-old son bounded excitedly ahead, ready for another run. Like many young South Koreans in the congested capital of Seoul, she and her husband escape to the nearby Taebaek Mountains to hit the slopes several times each winter, though she admitted they are still trying to find their legs as skiers.

headline: Who Called the Shots in Hanoi?
text: As any account of combat in the Vietnam War will tell you, America fought an “elusive enemy”: guerrillas who would strike and then disappear; battalion commanders who refused to engage in open battles. But there’s more to the cliché than most people realize. Even by 1967, America’s military, intelligence and civilian leaders had no real idea who was actually calling the shots in Hanoi.

headline: A New Beginning for Israel and the United States
text: It’s a fair bet that the first meeting on Wednesday between President Trump and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will feature big smiles and reassuring words. text: During the months after President Trump’s election, Israel and many of its supporters in the United States cheered as he promised a new, warmer relationship, such as a more lenient approach to settlements in the West Bank and moving the American embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

headline: Even in Texas, Mass Imprisonment Is Going Out of Style
text: It promises to be a bleak four years for liberals, who will spend it trying — and, most likely, failing — to defend health care, women’s rights, climate change action and other good things. But on one serious problem, continued progress is not only possible, it’s probable. That is reducing incarceration.

headline: Unearthing Justice in El Salvador
text: At the site of the worst massacre of El Salvador’s civil war, the remains of victims are still being exhumed and reburied.

headline: Unearthing Justice in El Salvador
text: The start of El Salvador’s civil war in 1980 was heralded by acts of incomprehensible violence: the assassination of Archbishop Oscar Romero while he celebrating Mass; the rape and murder of four American churchwomen. Yet those events paled in comparison to what happened the following year, when a U.S.-trained counterinsurgency force massacred more than 900 men, women and children in El Mozote and surrounding villages.

headline: Credit Suisse to Eliminate 5,500 Jobs in Latest Cost-Cutting Drive
text: LONDON — Credit Suisse said on Tuesday that it planned to eliminate more than 5,500 jobs by the end of this year as Tidjane Thiam, its chief executive, looks to further reduce costs and improve the lender’s prospects as it fell to its second consecutive annual loss.

headline: What Would You Like to Learn to Make by Hand?

headline: Caribbean’s Carnivals Tip Their Hats to Trinidad
text: We Caribbean carnival devotees, counting down the days until the region’s biggest bacchanal erupts on the streets of Port of Spain, Trinidad, on Feb. 27 and 28, have a dream. A dream that one day carnival will grace us with its life-affirming presence not once a year but once a month. That one day all of humanity can pause during mundane daily routines and take solace in the fact that right now, somewhere in the world, life is being measured out in music and dance and feathers and glitter, not conference calls and crowded commutes: Somewhere, it is carnival.

headline: Should Athletes Stick to Sports?
text: For the past few months, the sports media has been embroiled in a fight over “stick to sports.” The phrase comes from a common online rebuke directed at sportswriters and pundits and players and coaches and anyone in the world of sports, really, who takes a political stance on anything that doesn’t occur on a field or a court or in a locker room or front office. The dividing line is predictable: Many jocks and traditionalists argue for a separation of church and state; many young fans say that sports, just like everything else, is politics. But as the sports media critic Bryan Curtis has pointed out in The Ringer, the debate is mostly moot now: Trump’s presidency, with its daily explosions, has made it impossible to cover pro sports, even in the simplest box-score ways, without detouring onto the White House lawn. This comes, in part, from the way basic sports coverage works. Reporters ask questions before and after every game, and when the only thing anyone wants to talk about is Trump, some of those questions will be about the president.

headline: Is the ‘Anthropocene’ Epoch a Condemnation of Human Interference — or a Call for More?
text: Perhaps you’ve noticed, amid the hot invective and dry mockery of daily events in your social-media feeds, reports of the glaciers melting at each pole. Arctic ice cover reached record lows this summer and fall, while in Antarctica, we saw the continuing enlargement of an already massive crack in the region’s fourth-largest ice sheet, threatening its continued stability. The year 2016 was the hottest ever recorded, surpassing the previous record in 2015, which had in turn exceeded that of the previous hottest year ever recorded, 2014. Just as the world seemed poised to embark on a collective effort to wean itself off dependency on fossil fuels, its leading power elected as president a man who has claimed that global warming is a conspiracy invented by the Chinese and who went on to select as his secretary of state the chairman of Exxon Mobil. The choices they make will shape the future of all planetary life.

headline: Will Obamacare Really Go Under the Knife?
text: Six days after he was sworn in as America’s 45th president, Donald J. Trump traveled to Philadelphia to address Republican lawmakers at their annual retreat. Standing behind a lectern emblazoned with the presidential seal, Trump predicted, “This Congress is going to be the busiest Congress we’ve had in decades.” Being Trump, he could not resist ad-libbing a superlative: “Maybe ever. Maybe ever. Think of that.”

headline: The Snapchat Cohort Gets Into Politics, and Civics Is Cool
text: In Bridgette Francis’ Advanced Placement comparative government class at the College of Staten Island High School for International Studies, there was palpable excitement over a recent project — on the North American Free Trade Agreement.

headline: At the Grammys, Beyoncé and Adele Talk Up Motherhood
text: At the 59th annual Grammy Awards on Sunday night, the much-anticipated contest between Beyoncé and Adele yielded, among other things, an unexpected conversation between them — not about music, or politics, or race, but about motherhood.

headline: Apple Tiptoes Into Producing Original Video but Plans to Pick Up Pace
text: DANA POINT, Calif. — Watch out, Netflix. Apple, the richest company in technology, is finally moving into original video content.

headline: Westminster Dog Show Photos: Up Close and Personal
text: There is a flurry of activity around each booth as dogs are primped for competition. A walk behind the scenes at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show can be overwhelming. But a close look reveals what makes each breed unique. Above, Pippa, an English setter.

headline: Older Judges and Vacant Seats Give Trump Huge Power to Shape American Courts
text: Mr. Trump could soon find himself responsible for appointing a greater share of federal court judges than any first-term president in 40 years.

headline: Toshiba’s Chairman Resigns as Its Nuclear Power Losses Mount
text: TOKYO — Toshiba, the embattled technology conglomerate, said it planned to write off more than $6 billion and withdraw from the business of building nuclear power plants as the impact of a disastrous bet on American nuclear energy continued to rock a mainstay of corporate Japan.

headline: ‘The Daily’: What to Expect From Trump and Israel

text: Updated, 10:24 a.m.
